text:
Perfect!  Followed the recipe to a T and it was great.  There were a TON of leftovers. I used a 5 pound roast.  I put some of the extra meat in the fridge for later and still had a lot of leftover meat.  I filled my muffin pan with scoops of meat.  Each individual muffin tin holds the same as a typical sandwich.  I put the muffin tin in the freezer and froze the individual serving size leftovers.  After about 2 hours I took the tin out removed the meat  muffins.  Next they went into a ziploc and they will not all stick together.  To reheat just pop one in the microwave on 50% power.  These are great for a quick sandwich, with rice, with beans, or with eggs.

text:
Absolutely delicious!!! I would give this one 10 stars! I cooked on low for 10 hours, then shredded and kept it on warm for a couple more hours. I am seriously keeping this recipe forever. This is the perfect weekend bbq/potluck food, and went great with grilled corn on the cob and red potato salad. Also, when you shred the meat you can remove most of the fat. I think you could do without the oil. I used kraft honey bbq sauce - just what I had on hand. SOOOO tasty. You can't stop eating this.

Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! I've made it several times and everyone always goes crazy for it. I use a 6-7 lb. bone-in shoulder. I've used a deboned and a bone-in and the bone-in definitely comes out a little tastier. I leave out the oil and the chicken broth, because I think the broth makes it too juicy and I just don't think the oil is necessary. Instead, I just put in the entire bottle of barbeque sauce. I use like 10 cloves of garlic and a huge vidalia onion. You don't have to bother chopping up the onions or garlic too small because by the time it's done, they're all dissolved. I put in closer to 1/2 cup brown sugar, 8 or so drops of Liquid Smoke, two tablespoons of chili powder and a heaping tablespoon of cinnamon. In my opinion, and I think everyone I've fed this to would agree, the cinnamon is KEY. It makes it SO GOOD and adds such a depth of flavor. The recipe doesn't mention this, but make sure you put the roast in the slow cooker fat side up so it can drip down into the meat while it cooks. I cook it on low overnight for about 12 hours, then pull it and remove all the fat, strain the liquid and add it all back to the cooker for another 4 hours or so. The leftovers really do taste better every day. Make sure to make a semi-sweet southern slaw to go along with it - HEAVEN!  ;)

text:
Made this with a 6 lb. pork loin roast I had bought on reduced for quick sale. I followed the ingredients increased for my size of roast, except for using dry mustard in lieu of prepared and adding liquid smoke. I cooked on high two hours and then low for seven. I took the meat out and it shredded with complete ease two hours before serving, then placed back in the crockpot. There was alot of liquid and needed to reduce a good two cups worth after placing the shredded meat back in the crockpot. Added a bit of BBQ sauce and liquid smoke at that point to give the meat a bit more flavor, even though it was tender, still lacked that BBQ flavor. After another two hours this was the best tasting pork I've evern made in the slow cooker. Our guest even requested to take home some for lunch the next day. I'm not sure I'd add the broth next time, I feel the fat in the meat made plenty of juice.  *Note when placing meat in crockpot, always leave the fat side on top so the juices sink down into the meat while cooking...read that somewhere.

I was so excited to try this, but ended up a little disappointed. Although it was very easy to get together and the pork turned out perfectly and just fell apart, the taste just wasn't doing it for me. It was way too sweet for me, I was hoping for more of that smoky flavor. If I make this again I won't be adding any sugar, maybe more vinegar and maybe some liquid smoke to give it that pulled pork flavor.

text:
HOLY COW!  I put this roast in the slow cooker for a full 24 hours, on Low the entire time.  I turned at 4 hours and again at 12 (although at 12, it just fell apart and continued to do so throughout the day).  At the end of the 24 hours, the meat was dark brown from soaking up sauce and the most incredibly rich, moist, tangy and delicious BBQ that I have ever had in my entire life.  It was so juicy and delicious that we didn't even need any extra sauce or additions.  I can't believe how amazing this was.  Would HIGHLY recommend cooking for a full 24 hours on low if you can plan it that way.  Great with beef roast, too!

text:
LOVE THIS RECIPE!! I doubled because I had an 8-9 lb. roast.  I did everything according to recipe EXCEPT I didn't use oil (NO NEED!), and no chicken broth (no room & no need!), AND no Thyme as I AM NOT A LOVER, Sweet Baby Ray's Sweet & Spicy (because this is the BEST for pulled pork), placed onion slices on the bottom of crock pot, placed my large roast on top of onions, mixed all the other ingredients in a bowl and poured over roast turning several times to coat.  Made sure fat side of roast was on top!  Set Crock Pot for 10 hours, after 5 hours removed pork and shredded, removed bone, placed everything back in sauce, covered and cooked for 7 hours longer (ended up being a total of 12+ hours~the longer the BETTER!  YUM, YUM, YUM!!  Served with Greek Pasta Salad (made the day prior), corn on the cobb and apple sauce.  Definitely toasted the buttered buns (which is a GREAT touch) and my family ages 8 to 54 GOBBLED IT UP!!!  I always make much more so I have leftovers (even better the next day), and extra to freeze as well (for a later date).  THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR THIS RECIPE.  I have made pulled pork several different ways and I NOW think that this is my NEW FAVORITE!!  LOVE LOVE, and THANKS AGAIN!  HAVE A FULFILLING DAY!  :)

Excellent recipe. I made this for a pot luck at work and it was a huge hit! I followed the recipe almost exactly, but did not use the chili powder (I was out). I seasoned the meat with Famous Dave's Rib Rub and added a tsp of liquid smoke. I cooked it for 8 hours. The meat was falling apart, I had a hard time getting it out of the crockpot to pull it apart.  There was a lot of liquid left so I ladled some over the pulled meat and discarded the rest. Served on rolls with Serbian syle coleslaw.  DELICIOUS!!

text:
Very good pulled pork. My problem was the sauce was too runny I couldn't really taste the flavor of the sauce and the flavor didn't stick to the meat. My solution..after the pork was removed and shreded, I dissolved 2 TBSP corn startch in 1 TBSP apple cider vinegar and added it to the sauce. It thickened right up so the flavor (which was amazing once thickened)actually stuck to the meat. It was the first time my husband asked for seconds when I made pulled pork.

text:
This is AWESOME! This will be my go-to recipe for pulled pork from now on. The only change I made was omitting the oil as I just couldn't see the need for it and reduced the thyme to a little less than a teaspoon. After shredding the meat, I poured the liquid into a measuring cup which separates the grease from the other liquid, then poured about half of the liquid back in with the meat. There will be a LOT of liquid, which is fine, but you don't need that much in the end. Try this! You will not be disappointed!

text:
10 stars would be a better rating for this one. We absolutely LOVED this pulled pork. The flavors are perfectly balanced. The cider vinegar is a must for this type of pulled pork, so don't leave it out. When you add the pork back to the slow cooker, it soaks up all that flavorful slow-cooked juice and is just divine. Do put it back in, you'll be glad that you did. Didn't change any of the ingredients, cooked on low for 10 hours, and look forward to homemade pulled pork many more times in the future. Hubster said it is THE best pulled pork he's ever had in his life. He is a big fan of pulled pork, so that says a lot. Thanks so much for sharing this stellar recipe!  :)

text:
First off this is the most amazing pork i have ever had.  I used a 8 lb pork shoulder bone in much better flavor when the meat has the bone in it.  I doubled the recipe i didn't use the oil which is not needed because the fat from the meat  makes the sauce oily enough also didn't use thyme because i just don't care for it.  cooking times i changed based on how big the meat was i cooked it for 7hrs on high then another 3hrs on low and omg it was falling apart amazing tenderness when i took it out it was already shredding it was so tender. couple things i would recommend is place the dice onions on the bottom and place the meat on it to avoid having the meat touch the bottom.  also make sure u place the meat fat side up to so that way the  fat drips into the sauce.  another big thing is the sauce will be oily u cant fix this because the meat is fatty dont trim the fat first because it keeps it moist while in the slow cooker also i didnt sear it first either the fat is easily removed when u shred it.  to avoid the oily sauce once it was done i placed a whole bottle of bbq in the pot and returned the meat to sauce all shredded and kept on the keep warm setting for 20 min then served makes a huge difference  next daythe sauce will thicken  also the bbq i used was called dinosaur bbq original. i used the meat for tacos and the next day for sandwiches  enjoy this recipe its awesome and remember  dont be discouraged from the oily sauce after  it will happen since the meat is fatty

None
text:
This recipe is the BOMB! Like many folks...this was my first time cooking a pork shoulder. The oly changes:
1-DO NOT add veggy oil. Are you crazy! Pork always makes its own oil.
2-1/2 can of beer instead of broth.
3-I smoked my meat for 1.5 hrs with a charcoal grill and hickory wood chips.
4-5lbs TRIMMED pork shoulder (I would suggest trimmed to reduse amount of oil)
5-2 heads of garlic (1 head crushed in pot when slow cooking. 1 head inserted in meat when smoking.
6-Remove meat from pot to shred (drain "juice" before putting meat back in pot. Add sauce along with the onions and garlic from the juice back to pot. Add juice accordingly...I like my pork not to jucy).
7-Enjoy.

text:
Made this for superbowl sunday and it was a hit with everyone!  I read a ton of reviews and since everyone said it was watery and too sweet I made a few changes to remedy this...I used half of the cider vinegar & half the chicken broth, and doubled the BBQ Sauce (1.5 cups - half Sweet Baby Ray's and half a Hickory Smoke BBQ sauce).  Cooked on low 12 hrs.  I still had to reduce it quite a bit after taking the meat out (I did this in 2 batches), but not a big deal since it reduced within a few mins.  With these changes it's a definite 5 star recipe.

text:
Excellent recipe.I used a 6.5 lb Boston butt and cooked it on low for about 9 hrs.Took out the meat ,removed as much fat as possible as I was shredding it. wrapped the meat separately and chilled the remaining meat juices in a pot overnight in the fridge.The fat solidified and I was able to remove it all!Then added some Sweet Baby Ray and Wahoo sauce to the liquid and then used a stick blender to smooth out the sauce.Added the meat back to the sauce and put it in the fridge overnight to intensify the flavor in the meat.Served on toasted sandwich buns -yum!!!

text:
I have made this recipe 3 times now. What I like to do after I have shredded the meat is add it to a hot skillet with some olive oil and brown it a little bit. I think it really brings out the flavor of the meat better. After it is brown (takes about 5-10 minutes, stir it a lot) I take a few ladles of the sauce from the crock pot and add them to the skillet. I butter and toast fresh bakery buns (Bollilo or Bratwurst) instead of commericially packaged hamburger buns. I like to add a slice of American cheese and a Claussen pickle slab and voila! Culinary AWESOMENESS!

text:
So Yummy. Made this for my partner and I and it is the best pork recipe I ever made. I omitted the thyme and clove because I didn't have any and you couldn't tell. I also put in a few dashes of hot sauce and liquid mesquite smoke. I only had a small two and half pound roast beings its just two of us' so I cut the recipe in half. Next time I will find a bigger roast. I also used 4 big cloves of garlic, we love garlic, but could of used more. I had to use red wine vinegar & beef broth beings that is what we had. It did make any difference it was so fabulous. A must have recipe. This is one of those recipes you keep secret, lol. I tried kaiser rolls toaster as per recipe and tried another on a plain hamburger bun and they were both great. This is not as hard as it may look, so easy. Make it in the morning and go about your day and dinner is ready. next time I will try this over white rice. YUMMY!

UPDATE: Made this again for the second time. I still could only find a 2.5lb pork roast. Again I omitted the thyme and clove because I don't have it & do not like clove anyway. I use Jack Daniels Original #7 Recipe  Barbecue sauce. That is so good. Again I used red wine vinegar & Chicken Broth. This time I did not cut the recipe because I wanted more sauce. Always add 4 cloves garlic, little more Worcestershire. I add a few dashes of hot sauce & Mesquite Liquid Smoke. This brings so much more flavor to the roast. About teaspoon each. Everyone asked me "What is that flavor?" It is those

Overall, an outstanding and super easy pulled pork recipe. Definitely a keeper!

text:
Delicious and easy recipe.  The only change I made was to remove the pork from the cooking sauce; and refrigerate the sauce until the fat came to the surface and skim it off...our pork shoulder had quite a bit of fat.  Then I shredded the pork and added it back to the sauce.  Whether this comes out as a "sweet" pulled pork or a smokey one is going to depend on the barbeque sauce you use.  My husband felt the one I used was too sweet for his taste so I'll adjust that for the next time...because there will be a next time for this one!

text:
To give more flavor:  1) left out chix broth-it's just flavored water anyway. 2) used 3 T of chili powder and should have used more.  It didn't make it hot, just deepened the flavor. 3) used 1/4 c  yellow mustard. 4) used a rich bbq sauce as the vinegar and mustard will spice it up.  5) 1 1/2 tsp liquid smoke. 6) and as always, more garlic. 

All the juices and fat rendered when cooking dilute the sauce so make sure it is very strong when you make it.

text:
I pulled out my measuring cups and spoons and followed this recipe to the "T." The only exception was I didn't have an "extra large" onion so I cut up two medium ones.
The flavor was good but I found it to be too runny for pulled pork, not nearly thick enough. I don't mind "sloppy joes" type stuff but when it makes the (toasted) buns like mush, I'm not terribly happy. We went through several napkins per person. Glad I didn't make this as a first-time dish for guests (a golden, rule, I know, but I break it constantly). I also expected it to be a little spicier - I think because of the chilli powder- but it wasn't spicy at all.
For the work included in this recipe, I'd rather throw a pork roast in the crockpot with some good high-quality bbq sauce and let it be. All the extra work wasn't worth it. Sorry.

text:
My husband I absolutely love this recipe.  The recipe says it is for 8 servings, but we got 14. 

The only addition I made was to add 3/4 tsp. Liquid Smoke to the liquid, as well as substituting dehydrated onion flakes for a large onion.  I took another reviewer's suggestion and shredded the pork and put it back in the crockpot for another half hour before serving.  

Then, with the leftovers, I removed the pork from the juices and spooned it into a muffin tin (12 small muffin-sized servings.  I did the same with the leftover juices.  

Put the pans in the freezer until pork mixture and sauce mixture is frozen and place them in a gallon-sized freezer bag.  Each muffin-sized portion (and of sauce, too) is enough for one sandwich and can be heated in the microwave for use.  Put in a little extra BBQ sauce on each bun if desired.  

My husband asked me to "please make this again" and I definitely will.  Freezing in individual portions makes it so much easier to use up the leftovers without them spoiling in the refrigerator.

Love this recipe!

None
text:
Perfect recipe and made in electric pressure cooker in 90 minutes. 

I cooked on high for 90 minutes and just increased water to 2 cups. 

I did not use any sugar because bbq sauce is sweet enough. 
Also did not use oil because pork releases its own oil,  and did not care to use any broth as I prefer the natural taste of the pulled pork to shine through. 
I also added some liquid smoke to taste for that authentic Texas type pulled pork flavor.

It was delicious and I prefer to use the pc to the slow cooker since I do not like to leave any cooking appliance on when I am not home, due to a previous house fire which was caused by an unattended slow cooker many years ago.

The pressure cooker recipe is really delicious, and fast too, and my Texas dinner guests visiting from Texas all gave it the thumbs up, and requested the recipe too. 

Great pc recipe if you do not want to use a slow cooker, or have no time to smoke or bbq a pork butt or pork shoulder for pulled pork recipes.

text:
So freaking good. The ONLY THINGS I do differently is I reduce the apple cider vinegar to 1/4 a cup and bring the chicken broth up to 3/4 a cup to replace the missing liquid from the AC vinegar. I do this because I do not like the acidic taste. However what you can do instead is make the recipe exactly as it’s written, and then taste it. If it is too acidic add 1/8th to 1/4th teaspoon baking soda to neutralize the acid without changing taste. It’s basic science and will save your meal if you’re sensitive to acidic taste :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-03-26T06:09:16.99
helpfulCount:

userID:
12990788
Display Name:
madhatter160
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
6
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out great.  My wife is not a huge pork fan, but she loved this.

I used a 6 quart oval slow cooker and the pork fit perfectly.  I used a Sweet Baby Ray's BBQ sauce and it gave it a nice sweetness.  Use something different if you're going for tangy.

I put everything in except the pork first and mixed it all together well.  Then I put the pork in and nestled it into the mixture until it was mostly covered and resting on the bottom of the crock.

When the pork was done cooking, there was a lot of liquid left.  So, I removed the pork and ran the liquid through a strainer.  Be sure to push all the solids against the strainer to get all the liquid out.  Next, I ran the liquid through a degreasing cup and into a large sauce pan.  Then I put the sauce pan on the stove and reduced the liquid until about half was remaining.

Once I was happy with the sauce, I shredded the pork and put it into the sauce.  I mixed the pork and the sauce well and then it was ready to serve.

text:
I followed the recipe to a "T" and the meat turned out super tender.  I am going to rate this at 3 stars.  I thought the taste of the apple cider vinegar was very strong.  If I made it again I would use white vinegar and reduce the amount of it by half.  The sauce was a little runnier than I would expect for a pulled BBQ recipe.

text:
I doubled this for a large gathering and just about everyone there was pleased with it. I cooked it in the slow cooker overnight on low for about 12 hours, then put it in the refrigerator the next morning. After it was cooled, we pulled the meat, put it in an oven-safe dish and drizzled it with honey BBQ sauce. Closer to dinnertime, I popped it in a 350 degree oven for about 30 minutes and it was perfect.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave the recipe as is 4 stars, because I feel that you do, like other reviewer said, have to add more BBQ sauce than what the recipe calls for.  I also think that taking the liquid that the pork cooks in out of the crock pot and putting onto the stove to reduce also is needed for those that like a more thick, sticky BBQ sauce.  I find that adding a bit of tomato paste and simmering for about 20 minutes or more greatly improves the sauce.  Also, I like to take an immersion blender and blend it until smooth.  I then shred the pork, put it back into the crock pot, add half of the reduced sauce, and use the other half for topping.  Yummy!  The ingredients in the recipe do make a very yummy sauce!

text:
All I can say is WOW!!! My husband is a BBQ sauce "snob", he raves about my homemade sauce and says that's all he will eat. Well, I decided to make this recipe and follow it for the sauce. The only things I did different was, I put the roast in slowcooker before going to bed, around 10:00 with the chicken broth and garlic. The next morning, shredded it, dumping the dripping, and started over with fresh chicken broth and followed recipe "except" used dried flaked onion. Let it slow cook few hrs. more with sauce, and OMG, it was "delish"! Hubby said he was pleasantly surprised, and it was definetly a keeper.

userID:

Display Name:
Laura Schultz
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2506997.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe. I read the reviews & made some changes. It turned out delicious. My family loved it. I made the pork the day before my get together & finished with the sauce the next day. I didn't add the vegetable oil, chicken broth, thyme or butter. I used a bourbon & brown sugar bar-b-que sauce. I cooked the pork (bone in) on low for 10 hours in the crock pot in the mixture & there was a lot of juice as mentioned. I shredded the pork & placed it in the fridge. I took 3/4 of the juice & refrigerated it overnight then in the morning I pulled off the layer of fat & then thickened up the sauce with cornstarch & water. I placed it all together in the crock pot on warm for a few hours & served on buns. I also made cole slaw from all recipes & it was a hit.

userID:

Display Name:
Silver Moon
isPro:

16

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall I thought this recipe to be fantastic.  My husband has been the cook in the family; he was in awe with the outcome.  I did make a few changes; I put McCormick grille master rub and salt and pepper on the roast and let it set overnight.  I also took the suggestion of other readers and mixed the sauce ingredients the night before.  I also placed the onion on the bottom of the slow cooker as others had suggested.  I also added a tablespoon of honey and 2 tbsp of liquid smoke to the sauce. I cut the vinegar to 1/4 cup As another reader had stated the sauce was not thick enouuugh so I thickened with cornstarch and a bit of water.  I felt there was too much sauce for the meat and if prepared it again I  would add less to the pulled pork and put the remaining sauce on the side. I cooked the pork in the sauce on low for about 7 hrs, pulled it apart and added back to the sauce for another 2 hrs.  I was delicious.

text:
Excellent recipe.  Pork turned out great. I used two 2 pound pork loins and used almost the full bottle of my favorite bbq sauce (Dinosaur sensuous slathering bar-b-que sauce) put it in the crock pot on low for about 10-12 hours, shredded it right in the crock pot and then stirred the pork in the juices, served with fresh Cole slaw ("Sweet restaurant slaw" recipe from this sight) there are hardly any leftovers every time I make this. I cut back just a little on the thyme and added several dashes of liquid smoke as others have suggested.

text:
Good recipe.  It was a bit too much an the vinegary side, and I love vinegar, but it may be because I made homemade barbecue sauce for this recipe.  Next time, I'll try a store bought kind or reduce the apple cider vinegar in the recipe if I use my homemade sauce again. (note for myself: if making my homemade sauce, eliminate salt and slightly reduce Worcestershire)  I also did not have yellow mustard since it's not something we use, so I substituted horseradish dijon.  At the end, I did feel like it was good but missing something, so I added some root beer (probably about 2/3 can) after reading some other recipes and then simmered in the slow cooker for a little while longer.  That seemed to do the trick.  Next time, I may add some hot sauce or cayenne for a little kick.

text:
I doubled this recipe since I had an 8+ lb. pork shoulder and it came out delicious! This recipe reallyrocks! Not only did we enjoy it but our company loved it and so did a picky 3 year old and 7 year old. That's impressive :0)  I cooked mine for 8 hours on low, shredded it and then put it into a 12-inch saucepan with the juices to reduce...which worked out wonderfully. It not only flavored the pork even more, but created a thicker sauce for our sandwiches. I will be making this again very soon and can only hope I have leftovers this time around! Thank you for sharing!

text:
This recipe was very easy and extremely satisfying!! My hubby could not stop saying how great it was from the moment he took a bite.. until we went to bed! LOL! It literally melts in your mouth. I used a 2.5lb Roast and kept the recipe the same minus the chili powder and thyme because the BBQ sauce I used was very spicy as it was. I cooked it on high for 2 hours then turned it down to low for the remaining 5 hours. Since I left the ingredient amount the same I had to drain a lot of the liquid b4 returning the shredded meat back to the cooker. It made for the best pulled pork I have literally EVER had!

Next time I might make it a day ahead, keep the meat out of the sauce after shredding, refrigerate sauce and meat separately overnight, pick the solidified fat off the top of the sauce, then combine and reheat (just to cut down on the fat a wee bit). text:
I followed this recipe exactly using 8lb bone-in pork. I typically like my BBQ tangy and spicy - NC style - but wanted to try something different. While my pork was properly cooked, the flavor of the sauce just didn't do it for me. It wasn't bad by any means - I just found it to be a bit too mild for my tastes. To note: I kept the sauce recipe at the same measurements even with a larger pork shoulder. Once I had the butt in the (large oval) crockpot I was glad I didn't double it because there simply wasn't that much room left over. It didn't matter because the amount of sauce was plenty for 8+lbs of pork. It was drowning. With that, I agree with others... no need to add oil and I don't feel the chicken broth added anything but unnecessary extra liquid. Thank you for sharing.

text:
Didn't change a thing to the recipe.. except.. After three attempts with good results I decided to make one small change. I took all the ingredients. Put them in a small bowl. and mixed them well. Left them to rest for about 30 minutes. Put the pork roast in the slow cooker and gently poured the marinade over the roast. covered and set on low for 10 hours. The mixing allowed the ingredients to mingle and made sure the sugar was in solution. No burning to the walls of the slow cooker.

userID:
10852014
Display Name:
CalGal
isPro:

followersCount:

5

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for company over the 4th of July.  I made it a day in advance and I'm glad I did.  I wasn't too impressed with the flavor when I took the pork shoulder out of the crock pot and started to pull the it, but letting the flavors marry overnight made a huge difference.  It was very good and my guests thoroughly enjoyed this pork served over Kaiser rolls, with sides of slaw and corn on the cob.  It was pretty "soupy," and I was concerned with fat.  So I remedied that by storing the meat separately and put the juice in a large measuring bowl over night.  Then I could easily skim off the fat and reduce the juices in a pan before adding the pork to heat it up the next day.

3

text:
Tried this again, used the exact measurements as stated in the recipes, except i used non stick spray instead of the oil, then added half of the copped onion on the bottom of the slow cooker, place pork on top of onions, pour on top of the roast: broth, vinegar, worchestshire,bbq sauce, mustard. Sprinkle on top of roast chili powder,thyme, and the remaining onion. Roasted for 6 hours on high. Great on Naan bread and restaurant style coleslaw.

text:
Outstanding recipe! I used this for a crowd of 40 and everyone raved over the meat. I cooked an 8.5lb, a 7.5lb and a 7lb and just doubled the ingredients for each. Cook time about 9 hours at 200 in my cast iron Le Creuset pots. I only added back about half the juices after straining out some fat. Served in a Kitchenaid 6QT Slow Cooker using my Presto griddle to toast buns.

text:
For a slow cooker "BBQ," this was pretty good. I used sweet baby ray's original sauce, but next time I will cut back on the brown sugar and up the cider vinegar. I might also up the mustard a little bit. I'll admit I am a BBQ snob, as I have my own smoker, but for a weeknight pinch, it came in handy when my son was begging for some BBQ. 

I really like the buttered & toasted buns, and I'll be doing that from now on with all my BBQ. We used pull-apart rolls that I buttered and toasted to make little sliders.

Bottom line: If I need another slow cooker BBQ, I will come back to this one.

text:
Family loved the flavor, me not so much. I didn't care for the overly vinegar taste so I added more BBQ sauce to counter the taste. It did turn out more liquidy so I removed most of it from the slow cooker and thickened it in a saucepan and then returned it to the slow cooker to marry up with the meat once I shreaded it. I will try this again but will probably add less vinegar, more garlic, more brown sugar (or honey), less chicken broth.

Cut back on the vinegar and added more chili powder and garlic.  I also salted the pork butt prior to adding the other ingredients.  Based on previous recommendations, I dumped half of the liquid and the remainder was the perfect amount.  Served them on slider buns with cole slaw and bbq sauce.  Got raves from everyone at the party!

text:
good recipe! I used country style ribs, there the pork butt ribs, same as pork butt roast only less fat.
I left out the thyme because we are not big on it.

after draining the liquids, pulled the pork and returned wih just a little bit of the jucies left in the crockpot, added 2 tsp of pepper, & a teaspoon of jack daniels mustard and added 1/4 bottle more of bbq sauce left in crockpot on low for an hr to keep warm.

perfect .............served with coleslaw from this site, ( moms coleslaw) fantastic and easy.

text:
This was excellent and was a big hit at the recent Super Bowl party!  I removed the liquid from the crock pot, however, before putting the meat back in.  Using a ladle, I then began to add back just enough liquid to keep the pork moist.  I also tried to save as much of the chopped onion back in to the meat as well.  I then added another cup of barbeque sauce for a little more bbq flavor.  Having too much liquid will ruin the pulled pork so it is necessary to add back only enough liquid to keep the port moist!

text:
Great recipe! But, like another reviewer I agree with leaving out the thyme. I made it with the thyme and it added an odd flavor to the meat. I will leave the thyme out next time I make it. I used the 6 hours on high variation which caused a little scorching on the bottom of the roast but not enough to negatively affect the flavor.  I added another 1/2 cup of BBQ sauce right at the end before spooning onto buns and it was perfect. I sent my old pulled pork recipe to the trash and replaced it with this one.

text:
Though I rate it 4 stars it could easily be 5 stars. Not sure the shoulder piece used in the recipe but mine resulted in very fatty juices. I followed the recipe and was too much fat. I then had to could off the meat to either drain or cook off a lot of the juice, per serving. When I do it again, (and I will),  I will modify the recipe by skimming the fat off the juice before adding the pulled pork back in, or just remove 80% of the liquid, then add more BBQ sauce if needed. I grew up on this stuff, and my memory is it needing more not less juice/sauce. But the taste is better in this recipe. Also I will add in liquid smoke next time. But a great recipe..

text:
WOW, so very good! First time I ever made pulled pork and it was delish!!  I will be making this again for sure! I made a few changes...I did not use the vegetable oil, it seemed unnecessary.  I also had only a hot and spicy BBQ sauce in the house, and I didn't want to overwhelm the dish, so I only used half a cup.  I also used a whole cup of chicken broth and upped the brown sugar to half a cup.  I completely omitted the mustard, as no one in the house likes it, and I don't ever buy it.  Small changes, excellent meal! Try it, you won't be sorry!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just let me say, you would be crazy to try any other recipe!!!  this one is the best.  I did not put all the ingredients in with the pork while it was cooking.  too much fat to drain out later and I didnt want to lose any of the seasonings upon draining and straining later.  Heres what i did: one day prior to serving, I cooked the pork roast in the crock pot for 5 hours til shreddable.  Then I strained out all the leftovers from the crockpot that was not juice......I then added all the ingredients and put the pork back in and pushed it all down so it was well coated with all the sauce.  I put it in the refrigerator for the next days Packer game.  It soaked up all the delicious flavor and was the best.  I will never used just barbecue sauce ever ever again.  This rocked!!!!

Overall I really liked the flavor of this recipe.  I did add a few more cloves of garlic for my personal taste.  I used a red onion because I prefer that flavor.  I used a 4 lb roast but you could easily increase that to maybe 5 for the amount of sauce the recipe makes. text:
This was a awesome dinner. Served to my husband and 4 kids all finicky eaters it was a family hit.  Turned out delicious melted in your mouth, fell apart, tender, juicy.  Next time I wont add the vegtable oil, it doesn't need it. I did add 1tsp. Hickory liquid smoke.  Used 4.5lb pork roast cooked low 10hrs, didn't even have to attend to it, plenty of juices and alot of meat, no bottom scorching.  Other than that followed the recipe.  Butter some extra large hamburger buns, placed them butter down in the oven to get a firm crusty bun a must otherwise the bun is to mushy for my taste after the juices hit it.  Thank for a wonderful dinner.

text:
Have to say, everyone was loving this pulled pork!  Myself included.  Only variation I had made was instead of using chili powder, I instead used some red cayenne pepper.  Same amount, just wanted to give it a little extra kick and it did.  I also used a "texas" style bbq sauce which also adds a little heat.  But it wasn't over bearing.  Even my wife, who isn't into spicey food so much, loved it.  Was my first time with a pork shoulder and this recipe was super easy (prepared on lunch break to be ready by dinner time when I got back home from work), and was delicious.

text:
Super easy to make, the hardest part of this recipe is being stuck in the house all day smelling it cook away!

When picking your BBQ sauce pick one that isn't hugely bold flavored because you really don't need the extra (we used bullseye and hubby thought it was a bit too much) And there will be lots of liquid left over, You can easily discard half while keeping the rest to moisten the meat!

Served with a coleslaw and it was a big hit! We'll for sure be doing this one again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This came out fantastic!  I made a couple changes.  1. I used a 6.9 lb pork shoulder with the bone because that was the smallest at the store. 2. I substituted a beer for the chicken broth (per another reviewer's suggestion) because I didn't have any chicken broth.  Because it was larger, I cooked it on high for 9 hours.  One mistake I made was not turning it over about halfway through, so the top ended up not as cooked as the bottom.  The rest was falling off the bone and so moist though. Both my husband and my 2 1/2 year old daughter LOVED it.  I used Sweet Baby Ray's Sweet and Spicy BBQ sauce and ended up using some more when I made the sandwich because I love the taste not necessarily because it needed it.  This had a great vinegar-y, spicy taste to the pork, which is my favorite kind of BBQ.  Edited to add: DO NOT USE THYME! I made this a second time and used 1 tsp of thyme because I couldn't remember if  I used it last time. Well it ruined the entire taste.   Yuck.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This turned out soooo good. I made this for a baby shower at work and everyone LOVED it. I mixed all the ingredients together except the chicken broth and dried thyme (didn't have any or couldn't find it) and poured it in the bottom of the crock pot, then put my frozen roast on top of that. I started it at 7 at night and let it cook on low until 6:30 am. The meat was so  tender it had already fallen off the bone. I shredded the pork and strained the liquid. Put the pork back in the crock pot and added about 1 or so cups of the strained liquid. Once I got to work I put it on low and added about half a big bottle of sweet baby rays sauce to it and cooked it on low until lunch. Everyone loved it there was none left. Will be making this a lot! Thanks

cookingguy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second time I've made it and would recommend a few extra steps and a change or two.
1. When shredding the meat, remove the fat.
2. Allow the liquid to cool and refrigerate overnight.  Skim the hardened grease from the top of the container.
3.  Reduce the liquid by boiling and thicken it slightly with 1 1/2 tsp of flour as you would gravy (flour and a little cold water)  The slightly thickened consistency helps keep the pork coated.  This in turn helps prevent the juice from soaking into and creating a soggy bun. 
4.  If you use an intensely flavoured BBQ sauce (which is many but not all of them), you may want to reduce the amount you use.  It can overwhelm the other ingredients in the sauce.  You can always add some to the sauce when thickening it.
5.  Because I only added 1/2 cup of BBQ sauce, I added just a little less than 1/8 tsp of smoke flavour.

text:
Rave reviews! Teaching youngers here though. Watched the vid. No can do. We chopped the onion, placed in cooker. Scored and salt n peppered the roast, placed in cooker fat cap up. Whisked remaining ingredients in a bowl, poured over roast.
10 hr over-night cook.
Shredded the roast. Instead of putting it back in the almost 2 qts liquid, reduced it to two cups, then poured over roast, more intense flavor! (See? Didn't change 1 ingredient!)
(We prefer Everett & Jones BBQ Sauce from Oakland, Ca., not an ad, just saying.)

text:
I like to work off base recipes and then kind of create my own thing.  Using this as a base recipe ended up with some of the best bbq pork I've ever had. I had. 1.5 pork tenderloin.  I used 3/4 cup of sweet & thick Heinz BBQ sauce and omitted the brown sugar. I added 3/4 cup of chicken broth and 1/4 cup of apple cider vinegar. I used a bay leaf and a tsp of thyme, 1/2 of a large white onion, paprika and black pepper sprinkle, 2 garlic cloves, couple squirts yellow mustard, onion powder and a tsp of liquid aminos.

text:
I would have given this recipe 5 stars but I did make some substitutions. Anyway, super easy and yummy!! THE OTHER REVIEWERS ARE RIGHT. Adding oil is pointless. There’s plenty of juice and oil in the end. And it does come out quite juicy/liquidy. I chose to remove it gently and NOT shred/pull the pork and fixed it with scalloped potatoes and green beans. And THEN for the left overs I I pulled it and made it for sandwiches. Just to keep things interesting. Do yourself a favor, sub the mustard for Sweet Baby Ray’s mustard BBQ sauce. So amazing!! Yum!! Followed another reviewer’s advice and added a dash of cinnamon. Added incredible depth of flavor. Will make this again and again!

text:
I followed this recipe almost as written. EASY & delicious. I cooked, low, overnight in my crockpot for 10 hours. The last hour, on high, without the cover as this seems to cook off any excess liquid. I did not use the chicken broth...as previous ppl noted it was not necessary. I shredded right in the crockpot & let it cool, then took off excess fat. It is perfect on the toasted rolls! BTW....I am not much of a cook so this was a pleasant surprise.

text:
WARNING!! This does NOT taste like BBQ.  This DOES taste like really good pot roast from Ecuador if you were to add a pinch of cinnamon.  NO BBQ pork EVER includes chili powder or onion as it ruins the flavor profile.  Not even in Texas where they'll fight you if try and put beans into their chili. Now, my wife is German so she had no idea she was making a batch of Yankee blasphemy for my southern family.  This might top the time she called my mom and asked what stores carried green tomatoes so she could make fried green tomatoes.  Anyway - just know what you're in for in case you've never made real BBQ.

city:

region:

country:

text:
So I followed what most people did. No chicken stock and no thyme. I doubled the recipe with 2 shoulders totalling 8 lbs and cooked it for 10 hours on low. I hate fat so with surgical precision I removed all the fat from the meat and shread it. My 8 lbs netted me 3 3/4 lbs of fat clean meat which is really shocking. I know it's pork but wow. I put it in the fridge over night. Meanwhile I strained the fluid and our that in the fridge overnight too. This morning I skimmed all the fat off the sauce and boiled it down to 1/2. It's thicker and more concentrated. I have just put the meat and the sauce back in the slow cooker and tossed it all together to mix. I'm leaving it there for 3 hours. At present it looks right and tastes decent so stay tuned. So far it has been a very easy project. I had hoped to get more than 3 3/4 lbs of pulled pork out of it but that's life.

Follow up. The consistency and juiciness of the meat is perfect and it's very tender. We are not a sweet meat family. I usually cut the sugar by half in recipes that call for it. I thought about it and should have gone with my instinct. Next time I make it I will cut the brown sugar by half but otherwise it was very good.
Review:
Rating:
5

2017-07-09T17:18:00.933

userID:
739789
Display Name:
Baby Whisperer
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5539519.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made a certain pulled pork recipe for several years, but decided it was time for a change.  I made this recipe, leaving out the chicken broth (as I did not have any) and the oil (no need for oil as pork is pretty oily).   I followed another reviewer's advice and mixed the sauce ingredients and poured them over the roast in the pot. I cooked my 4 lb bone-in roast for 10 hours on low in my slow cooker.  Also, I followed a different reviewer's advice and when the cooking was done, took the roast out and let it cool for about 20 min before shredding it and in the meantime, poured the liquid into a pan and reduced it on the stove for about 20 min.  I wanted the sauce a bit thicker so I thickened it with 2 TBS corn starch dissolved in 2 oz water,  then whisked it into the sauce until thickened.  This process is a must if you want the sauce to adhere to the meat, otherwise the sauce is too watery. Put all the pork back in the slow cooker and mix with the thickened sauce.  In the end- DELICIOUS!!!!  The best pulled pork I ever made!  Will definitely make again!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Had a bunch of people coming over and wanted to give this recipe a try. I put it all in the slow cooker (onions on the bottom, pork on top and then the marinade) the evening before and left it cooking on low for 24-hours. In the morning (12-hours in) I took the layer of fat off the top of the pork (it just fell away) and broke the pork up a little with a fork. Around lunchtime I skimmed off the oil and fat from the top and gave it all a good stir (and a taste, of course) - the pork had fallen apart completely on its own by this point and tasted delicious. I stirred (and taste-tested) it a couple more times through the afternoon as the marinade reduced and the porked turned a lush brown. By the evening there was very little liquid left, just a big pot of perfectly juicy and flavoursome pulled pork which garnered lots of compliments and recipe requests. Will definitely make this again.

text:
I just put this in the crock pot but I tasted the sauce and I know it's going to be perfect. Changes I made: I used a chili-infused olive oil instead of veg oil;  1/2 cup Guy Fieri's habanero-mustard wing sauce instead of plain mustard; and 1 T Cumin; and I cut slits in the roast and stuffed them with crushed garlic cloves, all due to personal preference. I didn't think about adding the liquid smoke. I'll run in there and add that. 
There was a little more than a cup of BBQ sauce in the bottle and a lot was stuck to the bottle so I poured the vinegar in the bottle, shook it well, then added it to the measuring cup I was using to make the sauce. No waste.
This is going to be wicked-good for Memorial Weekend Sammiches. It's going to be raining the whole time so we're bringing the bbq indoors. Thanks for the recipe. I know I'll be using this again and again. I'm already thinking of how good this will be in warm flour tortillas with Mexican rice and black beans.

text:
Made this for tonight's dinner and wow, so tender, moist and flavorful. I made this with a 3.25lb pork butt and let it cook in my slow cooker on high for 4.5 hours. It smelled awesome and I couldn't wait to dig in. I used a mesquite flavored bbq sauce to cook it in, then after shredding it (oh it was super tender) I lathered it with a sweet, smoky, tangy bbq sauce. Next time, I'll skip the chili powder and add smoked paprika and add more garlic.

text:
This has a wonderful flavor!  Just right, in my opinion.  Made as written, except I used about 4 lbs of frozen pork chops (you know when you buy pork chops in bulk, there are some that aren't shaped like a chop, and not really suitable for standard pork chop recipes?  I used those.)  Served on a toasted hoagie roll.  Put the leftovers in my muffin tin, as someone else suggested, and froze.  They do make a good 1-person serving.  I know, because my husband requested more of the pulled pork the very next day, so I thawed two and made sandwiches again!  A keeper!

None
text:
Tasty, but made these changes. Seasoned the pork with salt, pepper, and garlic powder. Place on hot gas grill and gave it a grilling/char on the outside. Placed in crock pot with onions, thyme, vinegar, and chicken broth. Cooked for the size of pork I had. Removed pork and shredded and separated the fat out. Also separated juices in crock pot. Returned juices, meat to crock pot and added barbeque sauce to my taste along with other ingredients. Simmer on low to blend flavors.

text:
Though not what I had originally expected, this recipe still turned out great! I used Kraft BBQ sauce, and cooked on low for ten hours. It wasn't really a problem, but I did notice that you have to eat up the sandwich pretty quick because the juice from the pork will drain into the bun (could probably strain pork). Also, in some of the photos of this recipe, I noticed that they many have added some plain BBQ sauce to the sandwich before eating. I would recommend adding some as a sort of condiment to the bun, because although the flavor of the pork was good, it could use an extra punch.

I have never had Texas Pulled Pork so this rating is basing on our own personal tastes and not whether or not this is authentic.  After cooking on low all day the roast was simmering in a lot of juice.  I shredded the meat and stirred back into the crock, but the juice did not help flavor the pork.  We still prefer "BBQ Pork for Sandwiches" which has fewer ingredients/more liquid but seems to yield tastier meat.

text:
Made this meal with the exact recipe using Open Pit (not my first choice but we had an over abundance of it) Before shredding, I took a little bite and thought that it was a bit too tangy and vinegary (and I love vinegar).  I also thought the thyme made a bit too much of a presence, but once I added the extra sweeter BBQ sauce, it was unnoticeable.

To save this meal, I added some sweeter, thicker BBQ sauce (maybe about a 5-second squirt of it) and some more brown sugar, which probably didn't do much. 

I let it cook on low for another hour so the shredded pork soaked up the juice and it was delicioso.

text:
Not up to the positives that were posted, but good results.  The meat turned out tender and I used a 4 lb butt. VERY important to trim away all external fat.  The result still had a lot of grease (typical for a butt) and I decanted the oil before putting the shredded meat back in the pot.  The variable in review results could be because of the type of BBQ sauce and I used Krafts regular.  I would not use as much vinegar next time because the sauce, mustard and the worcestershire already have a tang, and it overwhelms the dish and your house for six hours.  I used the thyme and the cayenne to recipe spec and the taste was just right. Ready to shred in 5 hours after cooking on HIGH.

Tried this recipe for the first time with a little less than 4 lbs of pork shoulder, and cooked it in the crock pot for 6 hours. It came out super moist and tender, wonderful flavor. My suggestion is that if you don't love the taste of apple cider vinegar, to use just slightly less. text:
I have done this one and it is really great. I did change a few things. I added a tablespoon of liquid smoke, an extra tablespoon or two of red wine vinegar, and used spicy brown mustard. I like the North Carolina vinegar barbecue, which is why I think I like the extra ingredients I used. Used pork loin as well, since I did not have the pork shoulder. Made extra sauce for the side. Freezes well, and has been a big hit at church and school functions. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I made this and I didn't know what to think of it. It reminded me more of seasonings put on stew beef. It wasn't bad but the base flavor didn't truly remind me of a pulled pork BBQ sandwich. The sauce as others mentioned was very runny. It does reduce if left on low but it never thickens. The next issue is there has to be liquid smoke in there because although I added a tablespoon it still didn't have a BBQ flavor. Both issues are due to the ingredients however. The 5 1/2 lb shoulder fell off the bone at 5 hours on high. The meat was moist and tender so I'm giving the recipe 3 stars.  A friend of mine made pulled pork at my house with the meat on low in the oven about 8 hours and used garlic powder instead of garlic cloves. He put salt, pepper and  season salt to taste and I have to say, his was better. He made his sauce on the stove and added to the meat after he trimmed and shredded it. The sauce was thick and good. He did return the meat/ sauce mixture back to the oven so they could marinate but it was delicious right then. His sauce was not runny after marinating in the oven either. Just a thought.

country:
None
text:
Adjust the vinegar and sugar based on your BBQ sauce.  This is great but could become very tangy or sweet depending on the sauce you start with.  There is a huge amount of juice.  I had 1.5 quarts! I used a 5 lb shoulder without increasing anything else.  I used beer instead of broth.  I reduced the juices without the meat and liked the result.  I am going to cook the next one on the stove so that I can take the lid off after the meat is mostly done.  This should let the liquid reduce without an extra step.  I offer two types of BBQ sauce and hot sauce so the guests can get their sandwich just like they want.
Review:

userID:
10170533
Display Name:
AdvenChef
isPro:

7
favoritesCount:
46
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a crowd and also grilled turkey legs and sausages the day I served this. I tend to read all the reviews as well as google other recipes for suggestions when cooking, so here's the modifications I made. I used an 18 oz bottle of BBQ sauce, Bavarian beer vinegar, red wine instead of chicken stock, omitted the oil and thyme and added more garlic, the onion and some green peppers, also chopped. I cooked this for 10 hours the day before my party and then shredded the meat and refrigerated the meat and sauce separately. The next day, I defatted the sauce (there wasn't really much fat) and heated everything back in the crockpot for about 2 hours. I served with small buns and this way people could have more than one entree. Since I had free time on the morning of the party, I prepared a large casserole of fancy Mac n cheese and popped that in the oven when the guests began arriving. Definitely a great, easy menu for a crowd.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall, this is a good recipe, largely dependent on the type of barbecue sauce used. You could probably omit the brown sugar and not miss it, as it is too sweet for my taste. Also, like other reviewers, I think it has too much liquid in the finished product. Reducing the liquid by half before adding the shredded pork and adding some liquid smoke would improve the taste. I've found that 10 to 12 hours on Low is the perfect cooking time. Have made this twice now and find that with these adjustments, might be a 4 star recipe.

Display Name:
mary_o

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3654385.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good...not 5 stars in my opinion. I made this with a 4.5# bone-in chuck pork roast. For MY taste...it was too onion-y (I put most on top...1" dices) and would not do that next time which "might" redeem the recipe. Also, the juice was just way too oily. I did not add oil (based on reviews) and painstakingly removed the fat when shredding. I read numerous reviews and decided to cook it on low over-night (approx 9 hours). I took it out to shred, and poured the juices into a sieve to remove the solids and then added the juice and shredded meat back into my Rival 6-qt crockpot for about 2 more hours. The meat was plenty tender and juicy. What I didn't love was the flavor.  I tried to doctor it up by adding more Sweet Baby Ray's Sauce...which helped.  I finally decided to put the meat in the fridge while I put the sauce on the stove to reduce due to it being fairly "watery".  I finally gave up on the sauce after a couple of hours - it thickened but was just too oily.  I served the meat, which I heated with an additional 1/2 - 3/4 cup BBQ sauce, with warmed BBQ sauce for those who wanted more BBQ flavor.  My company seemed to enjoy the meat. It was not "bad", just didn't bowl me over like "Slow Cooker Pulled Pork" recipe from this site. Because tastes vary, I do think this is worth giving a shot, but for my own taste, I am on the fence as to whether or not I am going to give it another shot with some changes.

Display Name:
cookinKat

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is outstanding!  I combined all the sauce ingredients the night before and stored that covered in the fridge so all the flavors would meld together. I followed the recipe just as it was except for the thyme and the oil. (I omitted both)  I also added 2 tbs of liquid smoke like another reader suggested. I cut up my onions the night before as well so that I wouldn't have a big fuss in the morning, and I liked the idea of putting the onion slices on the bottom to act as a rack for the meat. I started out by cooking on high for the first hour and then turned it down to low for the another 8 hours.  2 hours before guests arrived, I took the meat out of the cooker and shredded it on a platter....I poured the juices through a collander catching most of the fat and all of the onions.  I added a little cornstarch with cold water to thicken up the sauce.  I returned the meat to the slow cooker and then poured the sauce evenly over it all.  2 more hours this way on low and I served it on whole wheat buns with cole slaw, corn bread and big ol pickles!  A meal I'll be repeating for sure!

This is my go-to pulled pork recipe because I love how you make your own sauce instead of just totally relying on a bottled sauce. I mean, there's nothing wrong with a bottled sauce for one-step convenience, but this recipe has that made-from-scratch deliciousness that comes from adding a little of this and a little of that. I've made this several times, thinking I'd have leftovers for the next day. But no. Served with homemade apple coleslaw, this makes everyone beg for more. And I love it when they beg. Don't you?

text:
Before you start, know that this recipe has a LOT of leftover liquid, but it is very useful, so hang on to it in the freezer!

First time I made this it was pretty good. Wasn't quite enough bbq for my taste, so I added more. It gets 4 stars for being fairly easy, and making a lot of food (which was the point)

The second time through, I made a LOT of changes. Different portions of everything (mostly just guessing), and I seasoned the pork beforehand. I took out almost all of the juice and stored it in the freezer, and put the pork in the fridge overnight. The next morning I cooked it on low with some bbq, brown sugar, and some leftover drippings from the day before, and it turned out amazing. Definitely a good recipe.

This is the first time I've ever made pulled pork.  It smelled so good while it was cooking!  I followed the recipe exactly and it came out very watery so instead of putting the pork back into the juices, because I was worried it would be to runny,  I just added a whole bunch of Sweet Baby Ray's brown sugar BBQ sauce to the pulled pork and it was so delicious!  Everyone loved it!  We topped the sandwiches with the Easter Grass Slaw from this site and it was so good!

text:
I followed this recipe exactly but after I removed the pork and shredded it I drained all the liquid out of the crock, added the pork back, and drizzled with a touch of bottled barbeque sauce. I haven't found a slow cooker pulled pork recipe that I don't have to do that in the end. The pork needed salt but otherwise was a good method. We serve ours with toasted (sometimes buttered) french rolls and sweet pickles on top.

text:
Made this for my friends the other day. Followed recipe to a T, except I cooked it on high for 4 hours, and then slow for 3. 
I rarely cook pork, and didn't know that "pork butt" in fact comes from the shoulder. I used a 7.5 lb pork butt and doubled the rest of the ingredients.
IT WAS AMAZING!!!
My friend from Tennessee said it was the best pulled pork he's had in a long long time. 
Thanks for sharing!

Display Name:
chips247

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was sinful, it was so good!  I used a 7 pound pork shoulder butt, and so I used about 150% of everything in the sauce, to include the spices.  There was plenty of sauce left over, and after the pork finished in the slow cooker, I had to skim off some fat.  Next time, I might consider not increasing the amount of the ingredients for the sauce, even with the larger cut of meat.  Definitely toast or pan fry your buns because of the liquid that the meat holds after cooking.  I put our crock on "low" for about 7 hours, pulled the pork, returned the meat to the crock, then continued on "low" for another 3-4 hours.  Melt in your mouth good.  No need to eat out when you have this recipe!

text:
This was excellent!  Wonderful flavor.  I did add more barbeque sauce than it called for.  I removed the pork after 10 hrs., shredded it, then drained about half of the sauce; added pork back and even added additional barbeque sauce at that time.  It helped it be a little less watery.  I used a combo of Stubbs original barbque sauce and the spicy flavor. Also added a Tbls. of soy sauce.  Very good!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was WAY too sweet for us.  I'd make sure to watch the sugar vs. your choice of bbq sauce and the amount of sweet that will add to the taste.  Also, be sure the pork has very little fat covering it - I don't frequently make BBQ in a crock pot and ended up with a much fattier liquid than I wanted. I would also dice and not chop the onion so it cooks down more.  This was not my favorite recipe, I wanted more smoky bbq flavor with the ease of crock pot cooking.  I'll keep searching for one I like.

I made this recipe EXACTLY as written, and in the end I found it to be edible, but not pleasant.  It was WAY too sweet, and the barbecue sauce flavor was too much.  The texture did turn out great, and it looked fantastic, but when I bit into it, I just got this overwhelming tangy, way-too-sweet mouthful of barbecue.  I will either have to keep looking for another recipe or perhaps read some of the reviews to see if anyone had some suggestions to cut that sweetness.  Thanks for the recipe, but it's not my cup of tea.

text:
Fantastic!  You can vary the flavor by your choice of BBQ (spicy, mesquite, etc).  We use a slow cooker or a dutch oven on low for a real slow cooked taste based on the size of the roast. Remove the bones towards the end, turn up the heat and reduce the sauce & meat together for a thicker consistency. Delicious even without a bun!

text:
This recipe has wonderful flavor.  Since I was only cooking for two people, I used a smaller pork roast rather than the shoulder.  The taste was good, but the meat was a little dry.  You really need all the fat in the shoulder.  So if you're cooking for a crowd, don't waste money on a more expensive cut of meat.  Go for the shoulder as indicated in the recipe. You won't be disappointed.

text:
I would have to agree with the previous posters' reviews in that the sauce has no flavor.  I did take their advice and season the meat before slow cooking it but when I went to shred the pork, it still didn't have a lot of flavor.  I had to put even more salt in the sauce, more bbq sauce and almost a tablespoon of red pepper flakes!  After all of my doctoring, it is pretty good.  I had some leftovers and they will get eaten.  But will I make this recipe again?  Nope.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was totally not what I expected.  I ended up basically with a pork roast floating in a thin flavorless liquid. I ended up removing the roast from the liquid, pulled the meat apart, put it back in the slow cooker with about a cup of Sweet Baby Ray BBQ sauce with some teriyaki sauce added to it.  That helped a great deal.  Also, the meat needs to be seasoned prior to cooking.  I rubbed mine in seasoning salt, paprika, pepper, & Grill Mates mesquite and it was still bland.  I guess I'm just used to my meat having much more flavor than this turned out.  Will not be making this again. Update -- I am updating this rating because with the changes I made the meat is delicious the 2nd day.

text:
I live in Texas .  . . . this rocks. I make the recipe using only 2 lbs of meat and the meat-sauce ratio is just right for us. I also use Coleman's dry mustard rather than prepared. And if you don't have a slow cooker, brown the onions in the oil first, then brown the meat a bit, and add the sauce. I keep it at low for about 3-4 hours and it's great.

text:
I used the receipe as printed, but increased or  added to it as follows:  2 tbs of mustard  6 pound shoulder roast, increased barbeque sauce (sweet baby rays sauce) to 1 3/4 cups,  and added  2-3 tbs of cholulu hot sauce.     I changed meat preperation as follows: I rubbed shoulder roast with JOHN HENRYS PIG  RUB and cooked on charcoal grill at 275-300 for  1 1/2 - 2 hours with indirect heat to give the meat a smoked flavor.  I than placed the roast in the  slow cooker followed the recipe cooking directions.   The meat finished up with a spicey smokey taste. Adds about 2 hours to cooking time, but gives you more flavor. Thanks for great receipe, Qwikdraw

text:
This is very tasty!  I had leftover pork chops that I want to reuse in a different dish.  This was it!  I cut the recipe in half, shred 3 pork chops, sauteed the garlic and onions in a saucepan, added the other ingredients and left it on low for 15 minutes to let the flavors combine.  Then I added the pork chops and heated through.  It was a great way to use our leftovers.  I would also love to try this recipe as it was intended.

text:
Kept the recipe pretty much as is, and the kids (and others at the family gathering) loved it!  The only changes I made were:

- Using a bigger pork shoulder roast (5+pounds) and cooking it longer to compensate for the larger size.
- Used 1 cup of chicken broth instead of 1/2 cup (because the tetra pack came in 1c. size and to compensate for the larger roast). 

Huge success, and well-liked by all!  This is a way easier recipe than the one from my slow-cooker book at home - no searing and pre-cooking of the onions!

text:
I've been wanting to perfect my pork shoulder cooking both on the grill and in the crock pot.  On the grill I am 0 for 1 and in the crock pot I am 1 for 2.  My 1 in the crock pot was a GRAND SLAM thanks to this simple recipe.  The flavor is amazing and the pork pulls apart effortlessly.

The only mistake I made was doubling the entire recipe because I had twice the meat (pork shoulder).  Doubling works for everything except the cayenne.  Although it's fantastic to me (I love spicy foods) no one in my family, except my 9 year old, will touch the stuff.

Next time I make this recipe, which will be soon, I'll double the recipe but keep the cayenne as recommended.  

Thank you for saving my average.  Looking forward to trying it again so the whole family can experience the greatness.

text:
I used a 5 lb. pork loin.       The juice was to thin and it was more like it was boiled.  So I ended up taking it out of the crock pot after it had cooked the required time  6 hours.    I put it in my oven in a shallow pan and added about half the liquid from the crock pot and baked it at 350 for an additional hour to brown it and so the juice would cook down and thicken.     I will say it was ok after cooking it in the oven with the lid off the pan so the juice could thicken up and the pork could brown.    I doubt I will make this recipe again.

Display Name:
pondersosa

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/168284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
amazingly good in a short amount of time.  I followed this recommendation - though they cooked if for much longer - my results in 6 hours were perfect  - I pulled it out and shredded / added some more bbq sauce and put in the oven to warm until needed                                                   :
 I use a 6-7 lb. bone-in shoulder. I've used a deboned and a bone-in and the bone-in definitely comes out a little tastier. I leave out the oil and the chicken broth, because I think the broth makes it too juicy and I just don't think the oil is necessary. Instead, I just put in the entire bottle of barbeque sauce. I use like 10 cloves of garlic and a huge vidalia onion. You don't have to bother chopping up the onions or garlic too small because by the time it's done, they're all dissolved. I put in closer to 1/2 cup brown sugar, 8 or so drops of Liquid Smoke, two tablespoons of chili powder and a heaping tablespoon of cinnamon.

We ordered brisket and sausage from our favorite barbeque joint but I opted to try pulled pork on my own, thinking it would at least turn out good enough to fill up our guests bellies. region:

country:
None
text:
Very easy and straight forward recipe to follow. I made a 5lb roast so I adjusted the ingredients accordingly. I only added about 1tbsp of the brown sugar to have a more savory flavor. I also added S & P to the pork before putting in the slow cooker. Once done I strained the sauce, added a corn starch slurry, and reduced it in a pot before adding it to the meat. The pulled pork was very tender and flavorful. I'll use this recipe again!

text:
I followed the recipe exactly except I didn't add thyme, I even toasted the buns.  I thought this recipe turned out way too runny.   I had to take out most of the liquid when it was done because it was like soup.  The flavor was also pretty bland, so I ended up adding more BBQ sauce.   IF I was to ever make this again (because it was easy) I would only use half of the broth if any at all. (I think a dr. pepper or some other cola would be better.) I wouldn't use the oil at all it was super greasy.  I'd also add a dash of salt.

userID:
2765081
Display Name:
mbsosa
isPro:

46

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe a while back and didn’t enjoy it. So I decided to try one more time before writing it off. I’m so glad I did. Seems last time I probably didn’t get a good roast. This time it shredded much more easily. I omitted the thyme and oil as previous reviewers suggested. Cooked on high for 2 1/2 hours then low for another 3 1/2 hours and the meat was shredding easily at that point. Lastly, because I wanted a thicker sauce, I reduced the liquid from the crockpot (it takes a while as previous reviewers mentioned) and added a tablespoon of cornstarch. Now it’ll be my go to for pulled pork!

text:
My boyfriend and I absolutely love love love this recipe. We used to frequent a popular hipster BBQ joint near by regularly to have pulled pork. I stumbled upon this recipe and figured I give it a try; it's EVEN better than the popular spot in town. Last weekend we were feeling nostalgic and went for dinner at our old BBQ spot, $75.00 later and we left unsatisfied. Went to the market and picked up the ingredients and put it in the pot for this week. No more eating out and getting pulled pork! I did modify the recipe slightly; added 1/2 cup more broth and BBQ sauce, used a whole clove of fresh garlic and 1/4 cup more brown sugar ( gives it an extra tangy taste) also I cook it on low for 9-10 hours as another reviewer recommended. Comes out perfect every time and no matter how big of a pork shoulder I use there is NEVER left overs!!

text:
This was the best pulled pork i have ever had, made it for a large gatherine and every person there complimented the recipe! I did make a rub on the meat before I put in the the crockpot, I used salt, pepper, garlic powder, and McCormicks hamburger seasoning. After it was done cooking and I shredded the meat, I felt it needed more bbq sauce, so I added another 1/2-3/4 of a cup, and let the meat sit in the sauce for another two hours before serving. I will use this recipe again and again, and several people asked for it! Thank you!

country:
None
text:
This recipe is a winner! My tweaks: used white vinegar instead of apple cider, ran low on BBQ sauce so I added a couple dashes of ketchup, substituted a dollop of Better than Chicken bouillon for broth, and replaced  Yellow mustard  with Dijon (no veg. oil either). Mixed all ingredients and coated the pork shoulder (trimmed of fat). Braised in the crockpot set on low for 12 hrs, stirring  after 7 hrs (no need to shred as the meat easily fell apart).  Delicious and the sauce was not too runny.

text:
The best pulled pork recipe I’ve ever made and I haven’t even tried it yet! I used a 3.5lb pork loin and sweet baby rays brown sugar and hickory bbq sauce and it’s coming along perfect. I put everything in the pot and put the diced onion on top then sprinkled the brown sugar and let it carmelize for the first 90 min then I flipped the pork over and spooned the juice on top and added more brown sugar. I tried a little bit of the juice when I did this and man oh man it was perfect! Ill be serving it on potato rolls that I’m going to butter up and brown on the stove top. I’ll have coleslaw in the side. I’ll definitely be making this again and again.l and again!!

country:
None
text:
Though the meat came out incredibly tender (I cooked on low for the first three hours, high for the next three, followed by the warm setting till served)  the taste just wasn’t what I was expecting. I’m giving it three stars, as personally it represents just an average score. If you enjoy a slightly more sweet and sour taste, this is your recipe. What it lacked for what I was aiming for was a hint of smokiness and a little more molasses flavor.  I used a half and half mix of bulls eye and sweet baby ray’s sauce and it still lacked.  Would I make it again? Yes - it was easy and the ingredients were everything I had at home. Is this something I would make to impress a guest? Unfortunately no, I may shop the market some more to find that right crock pot recipe. 

Last note: This recipe lacks salt. If you make without using rub, additional salt is needed.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was amazing, but I made a couple of changes to send it over the top.
1.  I did not put the oil in the slow cooker. Instead I heated up a skillet to medium high heat, and use the oil to sear each side of the roast for 2 to 3 minutes.  It carmelized the meat and added a depth of flavor and texture to the recipe. I think everyone should do this. 
2. I personally don't like excessively sweet BBQ, so I slightly reduced the brown sugar and I made sure to use a barbecue sauce that was not overly sweet.  It was still plenty sweet enough to be called barbecue. This is really a matter of personal taste. 

This morning I put this barbecue pork (with a little extra BBQ sauce) on crispy hash browns with melted cheddar - it was to DIE for.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So delicious! This amazingly moist, tender, and flavourful pulled pork will have your mouth watering for more. Some tweaks I made:

1) No thyme / no chicken stock
2) Add 5 drops of liquid smoke
3) The sauce will come out extremely soupy due to the water from the pork shoulder. Put the liquid in a pan and reduce it to almost half, then mix it with the shredded pork. Don't use cornstarch to thicken it as you will get a diluted flavour from all the water in the sauce.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I come from a family of BBQ experts so I never really tried to compete on their level.  But when I saw this recipe and the reviews, I thought I would give my husband a treat since pulled pork is his go-to when we eat out. Well it was fabulous.  I followed the recipe to a T, and it came out perfectly.  There was a lot of sauce when I removed the pork to pull it, but I just put it in a saucepan to reduce while I was pulling the pork and used just enough of it to give the correct consistency to the finished product.  The best way to adjust this recipe to your taste without making significant alterations is to use your favorite BBQ sauce.  I use half KC Masterpiece Original and half Jim Dandy's Habanero for a little kick.  After my husband declared himself obsessed, I made this for my "expert" family members.  Guess what?  I'm now an expert too!

text:
Followed this recipe almost exactly, and my dad and I both had an awesome BBQ night. I followed others' reviews about dissolving 2 tbsp cornstarch in 1 tbsp apple cider vinegar and adding to the broth after taking the meat out for shredding. Really thickened it up and made the sauce saucy and sticky. Also, doubled the garlic because... garlic. Next time, I'll add more heat (spice); I felt this recipe was sweeter than I prefer.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my family’s absolute favourite pulled pork!
There are just two things we do differently: add an entire bottle of bbq sauce (we use original sweet baby rays) instead of one cup, and mix about a tablespoon of cornstarch in with the shredded pork & sauce at the end to thicken it up a bit. With those two adjustments, it comes out perfectly at 6 hours every time, and it provides enough to feed us for a few days!
The toasted buns are a really nice touch. We also make homemade coleslaw and serve it on top of the pulled pork between the buns. Sooooo good!

text:
I only had a 2 lb pork loin roast so I halved the recipe. Added the liquid smoke and substituted dry mustard as the other reviewers recommended. Sweet Baby Rays BBQ sauce. I put the garlic and onion in the bottom of my slow cooker, rubbed the roast with the dry ingredients and let it rest for an hour. Added the wet ingredients and let it cook on low for 9 hours overnight. We do not eat a lot of pork around here,  but this was delicious! Will make again, and will be a go-to for parties.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was a little worried as this was my first time making pulled pork.  I was also using a 14 lb pork shoulder butt for a large group.  I had to split the roast into 2 slow cookers. Doubling the other ingredients was more than enough.  Based on reviews I skipped the thyme.  Since I was serving it for a football party I started it the day before.  I cooked it, pulled it, separated the fat from the broth mixture and then refrigerated the pork overnight in the liquid.  The next day I reheated the pork for about 2 hours on high using only a cup or two of new chicken broth and BBQ sauce (Sweet Baby Rays Hickory and Brown Sugar was awesome).  I was concerned it would be dry but it wasn’t.  It turned out great!

userID:

Display Name:
Sandy LaBree

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5488717.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Do not add the barbecue sauce to the crock pot for cooking.  strain the cooking juices through  a sieve to a saucepan and simmer on high for one cup. Add the reduced braising juices back to the pulled pork, and then add your barbecue sauce to your taste to the pork you will use for sandwiches. This way, you can use the basic pulled pork recipe for tacos or any other recipe without having the barbecue sauce in it.

text:
I don't love the taste of meat (including pork) so like my pulled pork saucy. This was a great recipe (especially if you like the sauce taste as much or more than the pork taste)! Fairly easy to make: I used a pork butt instead of shoulder and didn't use any oil. After shredding the meat, I drained some of the sauce (it was pretty liquidy) and added some extra bbq sauce to thicken it a bit. Worked great. Ate it with some kohl rabi and apple coleslaw (which paired really well) and topped with jalapeno havarti.

Overall this was a great recipe, I've made it a few times.  I did find this recipe way too sweet (and I have a sweet tooth)!
I made some revisions: I use avocado oil instead of veg. oil; maple syrup instead of brown sugar (but less then 1/4 cup).  When I didn't have chicken broth I just added water.  I also added a bit of bourbon & a few squirts of ketchup; bay leaves and all spice balls.

city:
