country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. I make it exactly as listed and for the brand of barbecue (since this will effect your flavor a lot) I use Stubbs: Sticky Sweet.  Its fantastic. I find it a little runny after the cooking so I add a little more after its done to my liking. The other thing I change is I do a TEASPOON of the Chili Powder instead of a whole tablespoon because I find it cuts too hard on the other flavors when I do a whole tablespoon but thats just my preference, otherwise I'd rate this a 4.5 just because of the (in my opinion) excessive chili powder. Since thats not an option, I put four stars because I really really like this, except for the amount of chili powder and the fact I add extra bbq at the end I dont feel its fair to rate it five stars because I like it with my changes but I feel as a base this is a great recipe.

How did i not realize how easy a slow cooker was?

Tender, juicy, flavourful...made it with 2 adjustments others recommended: leave out chicken stock but use a whole bottle of bbq sauce. Glad I did or it would have been way too liquidy.
There was a flavour I didn't like and I think it might have been the apple cider vinegar which came through VERY strongly.
(I messed up the cooking time...couldn't figure out why it was so tough at the 6 hour mark...just see now the recipe said to cook it on high. So, it took my roast 9 hours to tenderize on low and I had to stay up until 3:30 in the morning. My mistake, don't make it yours. I'll make it again without the apple cider vinegar.

text:
I liked this recipe but some things you need to know. Oil is not ever needed in slow cookers. I never use it. The second thing is that this recipe has too much vinegar. I use about half of what is listed. I also usually substitute chipotle powder for the chili powder (but not as much) to get some heat.

text:
I used red wine vinegar because the apple cider vinegar had expired and I also used onion powder because of time and it turned out great! My only critique is the the BBQ sauce was sweet and made the pork a bit on the sweet side so I plan to use a more smokey/hickory flavored BBQ sauce the next time I make this. Otherwise it seems like there is plenty of room to adjust the flavors to anyone's liking. This is easily one of my favorite slow cooker recipes.

userID:
23807916
Display Name:
Rachel
isPro:
False

1

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5458896.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked the flavors in this so much! However, I did not like the method. Concerning the fat, there is a much easier way to do this. I used a pork loin and cooked it in Beef Broth and Apple Cider Vinegar. I did this on high for 6 hours. When my timer beeped I took out the loins and drained the broth. This took out much of the fat in itself. I put the pork loin back in and then added the flavors that were in the recipe. I doubled them because of the size of my loin. I put the slow cooker on low (warm would work just as well) and kept it there until I was ready to serve. None of the flavors were wasted, as when I was ready I could shred the meat in the slow cooker and mix it all in the sauce which became a little thicker. Everything incorporated very nicely and my family loved it! (My choice of BBQ is Sweet Baby Rays Original as well)

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe at least a dozen times now, and varied the recipe after the 3rd cook! I decided to review after this cook because it was just so #$%^&* good! Rubbed the seasoning, "{Paprika, Cayenne, Onion Powder, Garlic Powder, Cumin, Ginger, Salt, Pepper, and Brown Sugar, ea  tbsp}" onto the butt and slow cooked for 8.5 hrs and let rest for 2 hrs, the Pork Shoulder Butt was 9.2 Ibs. no liquid added, that meant no vinegar, no broth and no mustard, except  1 tbsp of soy sauce, 1 tbsp of worcestershire sauce and 2 tbsp of Wrights Hickory Smoke the juice from the butt rendered as it cooked and shredded after a total of 12 hrs however again, only cooked 8.5 hrs at 225f and a total rest time of 4 hrs, 2 in oven turned off and 2 sitting out of oven and it shred like absolutely nothing ......... Awesome Basic Recipe to explore as you wish! The recipe was cooked in a Lodge 9 quart Dutch cast iron Oven.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe smelled awesome while I was cooking. When finished, I dipped the liquid out of the slow cooker and then shredded the pork inside the cooker. I then added back liquid as I shredded to get the right amount of liquid. I was afraid it would be too liquidy if I used all the juice. The first thing I noticed when I tasted was that it needed some salt. I rechecked the recipe to be sure I hadn’t left it out. I would think it could use about 1/2 teaspoon of kosher salt stirred in at the beginning. I also thought it needed a little more kick so I added about a 1/4 teaspoon of cayenne and stirred in. All said, great recipe and will definitely be doing it again,

text:
We really like this recipe. It's not super unhealthy and sweet like a lot of the recipes for pulled pork. it was easy to make. It had simple ingredients. I didn't have to run out to the store and buy ingredients. We are planning to make it again tomorrow  which is what reminded me I needed to write a review. Because the recipe calls for 1 cup of already made BBQ sauce I think that you get to impact the flavor of the sauce. You can pick a bold and spicy BBQ sauce or you could pick a mild garlic BBQ sauce. I like having this choice. Thanks for the recipe. I recommend it. Also, I am giving it 5 stars because there is nothing I would change about it.  it is simple and easy to make. Clean up is easy. Food tastes awesome.

text:
I made this tonight for a family get together and it was a huge hit!!! I used a 6lb pork butt roast  and cooked on low for 13 hours. I did not use oil, thyme, or broth. I added an extra tbsp of chili powder, doubled the brown sugar, used 10 cloves of garlic, & doubled the bbq sauce. I have tried a lot of slow cooker pulled pork recipes and this is by far my new favorite. I paired it with my cilantro lime coleslaw. The whole family was asking when I'm going to make this again!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cooked the roast overnight on low, about 13 hours. Then I removed the roast from the liquid and let it cool, just breaking it into junks (not shredding). I put the liquid in a bowl in the fridge to be able to skim the fat. Letting the roast sit and cooling the liquid was about 2 hours. Probably didn't need to be that long but it worked perfectly. Then the liquid and roast went back into the slow cooker on low for another 4 hours. Wonderful. By the time it was done, the meat was shredded. I followed the recipe exactly for a 7-1/2 lb. pork roast.

Added the cinnamon and 8 or 10 drops of liquid smoke.  Very nice deep flavor.  Also strained the liquid and added it back to the shredded pork.  Made this on Friday night to be served on Sunday for Christmas Eve.  Perfect, easy, crowd pleaser!

text:
Overall good and good flavor to the pork. A bit too much liquid for my liking so I would omit the chicken stock next time. I would also cut down on the onion - I think it only needed 1 medium sized. I used a 5 lb loin so I cooked it for about 6.5 hours. After if was shredded, I threw it in a pan with another two cups of BBQ sauce and let it incorporate. We like ours saucy and not so "wet".  I will make it again with these modifications.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good as written.  Extremely easy.  On recommendations from others, did not use vegetable oil. Only other changes I made were to increase chili powder to 2T and to mix all ingredients together in a bowl, then spoon some in bottom of crock pot before adding roast. Poured remainder over roast and cooked on high for 3 hours, then 2 on low. Shredded meat, put back in crock pot with sauce for another hour.  Sauce was very thin so thickened with 2T cornstarch dissolved in 3T chicken broth. Toasted rolls and slices of Provolone cheese made a perfect sandwich.  My picky son rated it "delicious".

userID:
7799674
Display Name:
draw34
isPro:
False

4

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best I've had so far. I did a few changes though. I used the mustard to rub the roast as a base for a dry rub. I then seared the roast on all sides before I put it in the slow cooker. I also mixed all the ingredients in a separate bowl before adding to the roast. When I removed the roast from the slow cooker  to shred, I also  strained the juice into  my gravy fat separator. After I remove the fat, I then reduced the juice by 25% before I returned it to the slow cooker with the onions that I had previously strained. I then returned the pulled pork to the slow cooker and held the temp until serving.
Review:

5

userID:
6859114
Display Name:
annette
isPro:
False
followersCount:

followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
13
favoritesCount:
35
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made 2 batches of this (8 lbs total).  In the first one I pretty much followed the recipe, but added a tsp of liquid smoke and omitted the oil.  It tasted ok, but I felt it was missing something.  I took a small amount  and mixed in my favorite BBQ sauce and it seemed to solve the problem, but IMO was still, just ok.  The next 4 lbs I prepared, I added a tablespoon of salt, 1 tsp liquid smoke (still omitted the oil) & wow, what a difference!  SALT!  Another reviewer also mentioned this and I too was surprised with all the rave reviews no one else has mentioned a lack of salt, and I'm not heavy handed on the salt, but it definitely needed additional flavor. For my party, I combined the two batches and had BBQ sauce on the side so people could top their sandwiches off if they liked.   At the end of the night there was only about a cup of the pulled pork  remaining.  I'd say overall it was a success, but I'd recommend adding salt - 1 tablespoon for 4 lbs of pork.
Review:
Rating:
5

2017-07-05T13:21:33.583

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it pretty much as recipe suggested but added more garlic and cayenne pepper/ crushed red pepper because the more spice the better. And again rough cut the onion because it will part of the sauce once it cooks for that long. If I'd had some liquid smoke I would've added it.  I also used pork butt because that's all I could find. I put the fatty side up to cook, and when meat was fully cooked I took it out and cut the fat off. Shredded meat and through back in the sauce. Definitely make some creamy slaw to go with it. Overall this was very very good.

text:
i left out the chicken stock as many suggested but since i use the "better than bouillon" paste instead of liquid i mixed some paste into the cider vinegar. Otherwise I followed the instructions and reduced the sauce down while I was shredding the pork, adjusted for seasoning with a spoonful more brown sugar, some salt, an a splash of vinegar and god was this good! Fed five big eaters in my house with leftovers. They're telling me it's the best pulled pork they've ever had!

None
text:
This is a simple recipe that yields flavorful results. Instead of chicken broth, I tried apple cider to mirror the apple flavor in the apple cider vinegar. It worked. Also, I wanted a stronger garlic punch, so I used garlic powder. I did use the raw onion, however.  After it had properly cooked, I removed the braising liquid to a small stockpot and, after de-fatting it, boiled that liquid down to a perfect sauce which I poured on the meat to infuse it with the sauce. A winner, pure and simple!

text:
I omitted the oil, as I did not see the need for it (the pork roast has it's own fat).  I used dark brown sugar instead of light brown sugar and spicy brown mustard instead of yellow mustard, as that is what I had on-hand.  I tweaked the recipe to suit our preference for a more bolder and spicier flavor by doubling-up on the sugar and mustard - and added 1/2 cup extra BBQ sauce.  Also, I added about 1.5 tsp sea salt.  This was a big hit with my family and I am adding it to our monthly dinner rotation.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe exactly as written!!!   And to the person who said it was too sweet and not smoky enough, you probably used a BBQ not to your liking.  1/4 cup brown sugar wouldn't make it too sweet but using a honey or brown sugar BBQ would add to that.  I suggest you use a vinegar based sauce such as the new Heinz Carolina Vinegar style (I almost cringe saying that because I like "mom and pop" type BBQ sauces and not big brand names but the stuff is good!)    It has a bit of a smoky taste too but definitely not sweet at all.  You could also add a bit of liquid smoke as you suggested.

text:
I used a pork butt with bone in, it was already seasoned from store with BBQ season so I skipped the chili power and just added a pinch of cumming to it. I used baby rays sweet and spicy sauce, a small onion instead of a large (large would have been good if I'd had it) and a chicken bolion cube with 1/2 cup water instead of the broth. I left out the thyme bc I didnt have any. This is a mild version of BBQ pulled pork - which my family and I loved - it didn't overwhelm the meat with too much sauce or flavor - it was A perfect amount of taste vs. meat. Oh and I just threw it all in a crock pot around 9 on high and by 2/3 o'clock i pulled the bone right out and we ate.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family LOVES this recipe.  Although I put it in my Insta-Pot to have it sooner.  We saute the onions in the pan, then add the other ingredients except veg. oil, followed by a pork shoulder of whatever size.  A 3 lb shoulder takes about 90 min plus maybe 15-20 of slow-release.  The 5 pound shoulder I did last night took over 2 hours, next time I would cut it in half first.  
After we shred the meat, we put it on a quarter cookie sheet and spread it out evenly and broil it on high to give it some nice crusty edges, before serving it with the buttered and grilled potato buns, with a side of bbq sauce.

text:
I have made this many times and love it.  What I do about a half hour before dinner is drain off all the liquid, shred the pork and add fresh barbecue sauce to the pork in the slow cooker.  I often add back a little of the cooking liquid too.   I let it go while I finish making everything else.  The result is a gooey yummy pulled pork with a ton of flavor!

text:
This is the first time that I have cooked a pork butt any way other than on my smoker.  This recipe did not measure up to pulled pork BBQ  from a smoker however it was pretty tasty and, in truth I guess that that is an unfair comparison.

On the plus side it was done in about 41/2 hours and I would have had to babysit the smoker for 10 to 12.

If I try it again I will reduce the amount of Liquid by  a third to a half and will eliminate the onion.

When it was all said and done;  It was pretty tasty on a bun with some cole slaw on top.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made several times. The first time exactly following the recipe. I have omitted the Thyme. It over-powered the entire dish and I only used 1 teaspoon.
Second change, since I have a "diabetic" in the household, I make the brown sugar using molasses and Splenda and use Kraft Hickory Smoke BBQ Sauce. BBQ sauces like "Sweet Baby Ray's" and "KC Masterpiece" are already very sweet. This way I have more control over the sugar content.
Finally, I "sear" the meat prior to placing in the crock-pot. I like the added color.
It is a great "base" recipe and I will use it, over and over. It is always fun to experiment with different seasonings and methods.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

text:
This is an excellent recipe!   I followed the ingredient list (no thyme) almost to the letter (did add a little mesquite liquid smoke) and slow cooked on low for approx. 18 hrs.   After pulling the pork, I also reduced the cooking juices until thickened and then added additional barbeque sauce ( Sweet Baby Rays Sweet & Spicy) and low cooked for 2 more hrs.  Reducing the juices eliminated any runniness.  Final was browning Brioche buns with butter and YEOOOWEEE GOOD!!  This was my 1st attempt and everyone thought I was a master barbeque chef!!

FollowsInstructions

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this a couple times now. After you shred the pork take 3/4 of the juices from the slow cooker and out them in a small sauce pan. Use a slotted spoon to extract the onions, and pork pieces. Mix 2 tablespoons of flower with some cold water and mix the paste into the saucepan to make a thicker sauce/ gravy. Take the remaining 1/4 of the juices and the extracted onions and mix that into the shredded pork. It is more than enough to flavour it and you get a thicker sauce for your sammies.  Angie's dad's coleslaw recipe on allrecipes.com goes great with this.

text:
The pork came out very tender but the sauce was just okay.  I was expecting something more flavorful with all the great ratings.  I cooked it for 10-12 hours on low and the pork when shredded wasn't runny in the sauce.  I found the sauce bland and added more barbecue sauce and some scriracha.  You might as well have added a sloppy joe type sauce.  That's what it tasted like to me.  Or maybe just use your favorite bottle bbq sauce.  Anyway, I wouldn't brag about the recipe to anyone and prob won't use again.

Made recipe exactly as written. text:
Easy and delicious !  No chili powder on hand, forgot thyme and still turned out well.  Added about a tsp. of smoke flavoring.  No need to add BBQ sauce.  Tastes great without !  Also....recipe did not call for trimming fat which I usually do for pulled pork.  A little tricky to pull off at the end but I think added to the moistness (cooked on low for 12 hours).  Topped with wilted arugula to mimic pork and broccoli rabe.  Yum !!!

text:
As a Native Texan raised on smoked meats & pit BBQ...this is the closest you can get the "easy way".  We have been using this recipe for over a year probably once a month and it's a huge favorite!  I follow the recipe to the letter, but after cooking & shredding I take about 1.5 cups of the cooking liquid (skim off most of the fat), mix it with 1.5 cups of fresh barbecue sauce, put it all back in the crock pot for an hour...it's AH-MAY-ZING!

Display Name:
Kelly Dargatz

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3832677.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this pulled pork using pork tenderloin.  I knew that tenderloin can be dry, and there seems to be a myth that it doesn't shred.  It shredded just fine. 
A few changes I made: I used 2 pounds of pork tenderloin (instead of 4 pounds of pork shoulder) which entailed 2- 1lb pieces.  Worried that it might become too dry and lean, I doubled the oil, and kept almost everything else about the recipe the same (same liquid 
and spice as original recipe).  I added a tsp of liquid smoke.
I cooked the recipe for 4 hours on high, then another 2 hours on low.
Husband really liked it.  We usually do a smoked pork shoulder with rub in our Bradley smoker, but that's his cooking baby.  We currently have 6 inches of snow on the ground and hubby's sick...so I thought I'd give this a try.
No where near as good as the Bradley smoker, but a relatively quick and easy, leaner, and pretty tasty pulled pork nonetheless.  Might make again.

text:
We enjoyed this but I won't make it again.  As several other reviewers commented, there is too much liquid at the end. When I took the pork out, I thickened the sauce over the stovetop with cornstarch/water  in order to get a thicker consistency.  The taste was good but that was extra cooking time I wasn't counting on. I may try this again with 1/2 the liquid as someone else recommended. (For those who are saying the Thyme is too strong...I believe you have to use ground thyme instead of thyme leaves).

text:
Great, Great.  I used a 5lbs. bone in shoulder, it really does add flavor!!  I browned it first in an iron skillet then rubbed it with  the mustard, then dusted it with a combo of basic rub and the thyme.  Next time I will add about 1 tea of liquid smoke to the chicken stock.  After shredding just place it back in the pot on the warm setting and let it absorb all that great sauce.  Don't skip this portion of the process.  I cooked it 12 hrs on low.

This recipe was perfect. I took the meat when my slow cooker cut off and it feel apart as I wanted. Then I took 2 forks and shredded the meat. I put the liquid that was in the slow cooker in the refrig to congeal the fat so we could remove it. Then we put the meat and liquid back in the cooker to keep warm with a small crockpot at the side full of BBQ sauce and used Hawaiian rolls for the slider. Everyone at the reunion loved it

text:
I doubled the recipe because my pork roast was nearly 8 pounds.  Other than leaving out the thyme, I followed the recipe and cooked it in crock-pot overnight.  I pulled the meat apart, discarding as much fat as possible.  I used a separator cup to get as much grease as possible out of the liquid before adding back to the pork.  I continued to cook on slow for a while longer before serving on buns with red slaw  Our family loved loved loved it.  We had a lot of leftover to enjoy again.  Will definitely make this again.

text:
Given the large quantity of great reviews, I was really hoping I'd like this recipe a lot more.  I followed it to a T, the only difference was I used about 3lbs of meat instead of 4lbs.  I reason I hesitate with this recipe is due to the amount of vinegar.  While I've had plenty of vinegar based BBQ sauces before, I feel that it overpowers in this dish.  If I make this again, I will either lower the amount significantly or cut it out completely.  Per other reviews, there is plenty of liquid in this dish & it wouldn't miss it.  Besides the vinegar, I really did like the flavor and ease of the recipe.

Used  a 5-3/4 lb. shoulder roast and altered recipe slightly using beer instead of broth, smoked paprika and ground mustard instead of prepared. Cooked it in slow cooker on low for 18 hours.  The amount of thin juice was excessive at 8 hours,  but after 18 hours, it dissipated to the proper thickness.  I added a little more beer to moisten it and revive the beer flavor.  Everyone loved it!!   Next time I would omit the salt though.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After the cooking period the crockpot was literally half full with a very watery liquid (plus the fat from the pork). It completely watered down any taste of bbq sauce and most of the seasoning and wouldn't stick to any of the meat. I drained all of the liquid. I then took half of the liquid and put it in a small saucepan on the stop top. I added more bbq sauce and liquid smoke and then whisked in some corn starch and let it simmer for a few minutes until it was thicker. I added it back to the pulled pork and left on warm for 30 minutes. The pork with this sauce was delicious!!!

Display Name:
lampim
isPro:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3736217.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This came out great with a few tweaks.  I only had a petite roast (about 2.5 lbs) so i cut all ingredients in half except I doubled the worcestershire sauce  and used the 1 full Tbsp of chili powder and full 1/4 cup brown sugar. I also added a 1/2 tsp liquid smoke.  I also left out the oil and onion. I sliced the roast down the middle so 2 halves fit side by side in the crockpot which allows them to sit in the broth better. I also grilled the roasts on the gas grill (high, 3 mins. per side) to get a little charring on the outside.  I cooked it low for 8 hours in the crockpot, removed the meat and allowed it to cool. then I reduced the remaining broth by 1/2 by cooking it down on the stove top.  squishing the meat by hand caused it to fall apart and I added it back into the sauce which the meat soaked up 100% after a a few more mins in the crockpot (no drippy sauce at all).
it came out FANTASTIC!
thank you!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2016-07-09T05:24:15.753
helpfulCount:

text:
I made 65lbs of pork for 120 guests for our RV Park 4th of July celebration.  I chose it based on reviews and did a trial run with taste testers but was disappointed due to lack of flavor so I changed the chicken broth to Pepsi and the original bbq sauce to Hickory to add flavor.  It was better but still I think my regular Pepsi and brown sugar would've been better and a whole lot simpler.  I cooked some on high for 5hrs, low 10hrs, and low 12hrs. I recommend the 10hrs...the meat slides off the bone and is easy to shred with 2 forks.  This recipe was just "ok" and everyone added extra bbq sauce on top. Kind of dissapointed.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3608500.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cut of meat used:
Pork shoulder

Omitted the following ingredients:
yellow mustard
onion
garlic
thyme

Barbecue sauce used:
Sweet Baby Ray's Hickory and brown sugar

Cook time:
Low 10-12 hours

After cooking:
Remove meat for shredding
Add about 1-1.5 cups more barbecue sauce (or to taste)
thicken liquid in crock pot with 1-2 TBS corn starch and cold water
Return shredded pork to slow cooker
Keep warm until ready to serve

text:
My family and I love pulled pork and I keep my eyes open for different recipes to try.  The apple cider vinegar sounded like an excellent idea!   I did make changes based on other reviews (no oil, no broth, no thyme) and I added a fair amount of ground chipotle (family favorite) and liquid hickory smoke--it was EXCELLENT.  Took it to a picnic and had very little left over (I'm glad I had some to enjoy at home).  My boys said it was the best yet and have already asked for it again.  I use leaner pork loin to start with, and skim the fat before combining everything so the flavors are strong and satisfying--not heavy or oily. THANK YOU for this recipe!

This makes a ton! I used a 3lb piece of pork loin (not tenderloin) and dumped it in the slow cooker still frozen. Ran out of Worcestershire so I subbed soy. Also threw in peel from half an orange and 1/2t hickory liquid smoke. 7-8 hours on high (due to being frozen) and was perfect. I'm in Boston and I fed it to people from North Carolina who approved (and they know their pulled pork)!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6546925.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
THIS is the pulled pork recipe I've been looking for.  The sauce is what was missing on the other pulled pork recipes on this site. Old fashioned, perfect pulled pork.  Just the right amount of tang.  
The only thing I didn't do was use smoke flavoring.  We don't care for it.  Instead, I started a slow fire, with wood chips on my grill.  I put all the charcoal and water soaked mesquite chips on one side and the pork roast on the other.   My purpose was to smoke it, since I don't have a smoker.  I left it in there for several hours, turning it every half hour.  Seasoned using basic seasonings.  Then added it to the slow cooker.  Yes, it took a long time-but the results were worth it.

text:
Needs a 1/2-1 tsp of liquid smoke depending on your BBQ sauce. 1/2-1tsp crushed red peppers if you like it spicy. Other then that, this pulled pork is a great one. Make sure to use the best BBQ sauce possible. Don't buy cheap stuff like Kraft BBQ sauce. It will taste way better if you spend a few more bucks on Stubbs sauce, or Sweet Baby Rays is pretty good.

userID:
18097355
Display Name:
Spriggzy
isPro:

followersCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this twice.
First time I left out the chilli and sugar, left the skin/fat on until just before pulling, doubled the recipe for a larger piece of pork. After 5hrs, it was very runny so I reduced the liquid over the stove and added back to the meat at the end. left for another 1hr. it was delicious but very fatty!

Second time, I used the original recipes ratios with a larger piece of pork (5-6 pound shoulder)
I used 1/4 cup of the sugar, did not use chilli, added liquid smoke. I also cooked 3 onions in oil and 4 tsp smoked paprika to get it caramelised and smokey before I added to slow cooker.
I then removed all the skin from the pork, browned the pork shoulder before putting everything in the slow cooker. 
I kept the skin/fat for crackling at the end.
Cooked this one for 8hrs.

Both times cooking this, there was ALOT of liquid and I had to separate and reduce this before adding back to the pork after pulling it. Well worth it for max flavour!!! 

Served with crackling on the side.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really good.  I used a 2.5 lb. pork shoulder roast, trimmed the fat before cooking.  I halved the sauce ingredients(used about 3/4 cup bbq sauce), but omitted the veg. oil, chicken broth, and thyme. Cooked on high for five hours, removed and shredded meat.  Poured sauce in skillet and let boil on stove for a few minutes to reduce, also skimmed off a little fat.  Returned meat to slow cooker, covered with sauce and left for two more hours on low, stirred a couple of times.  Consistency was just right for sandwiches.  Served on grilled ciabatta buns, extra bbq sauce optional.  I didn't need any , it was delicious!  Oh, and I did sprinkle the shredded meat with a little salt.

I made this for my husband and several friends. They loved it! I used about a 5 lb. pork shoulder blade roast and used everything in the recipe except the thyme. I cooked it for 7 hrs on low, 2 hrs on high, and an additional hour on high after it was shredded. It was so juicy and delicious, and the house smelled amazing while it was cooking! We poured it over hoagie buns with coleslaw and fries on the side. It was easy to throw together before leaving for work in the morning, and it was ready just in time for dinner. text:
Great stuff! I altered the recipe a bit as per the advice of others in the comments. I left out the veg oil and chicken stock, used oregano rather than thyme, and changed the chili powder for a mix of cayene and smoked paprika. Those who complain that it doesn't have that smokey BBQ flavour, well, it won't simply because it's been nowhere near smoke! I might try using liquid smoke at some point, or it can be finished off in a foil roasting tray under the lid of a hot smokey BBQ to try and impart some of that smokeyness.

This recipe yielded the best pulled pork I've ever made.  I started with a lean shoulder, which was nice and followed the recipe with a few exceptions.  1. I increased the yellow mustard to about 3 tbsp, 2. I cut the brown sugar slightly and 3. I omitted the thyme (I was all out!). Also, we enjoyed our sandwiches on plain, fresh white bread.... Which I think was perfect!  Sauce had a great tang and the pork was super tender.  This will be my go-to pork shoulder going forward - even my kids (5, 8) had seconds!

None
text:
This was sensational!!!  I cut all of the fat off the pork before popping it into the slow cooker and just turned it every 2-3 hours to make sure it stayed moist.  I slow cooked it for 8 hours, then took the pork out and shredded it.  I tipped half of the juices out of the slow cooker, squeezed a generous amount of smoky BBQ sauce into the mix together with a heaped tablespoon of cornflour to thicken it up, then put the shredded meat back in with the juices and slow cooked for another 1 1-2 hours.  Heaps left over but my family absolutely loved it!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The four stars are for the recipe exactly as written.  And with apologies to those who would prefer that we review the recipe exactly as written:  I substitute root beer for the chicken stock and don't add the barbeque sauce until after the pork is shredded.   I  remove the pork and let it sit a few minutes before shredding in the expectation that some juices will seep back into the meat.  l reduce and thicken the cooking juices with corn starch and I add the barbeqe sauce at the end before adding the thickened sauce to the shredded pork.   I freeze any leftovers in  two serving packets.
And I serve with mashed potatoe rather than buns.  It is a great recipe that I come back to every time I find pork on sale.

text:
The taste of thyme was too pronounced and there was a lot of liquid.  After I shredded it and before I put it back into the crock pot, I ladled out an extra 2 1/2cups liquid.  I also added extra BBQ sauce to try and combat the thyme.  Whether or not you ladle out some of the sauce before adding the pork back to the crock pot is entirely personal preference though, as is the amount of thyme.  We're not huge on it in my house, so next time I make this I'll halve the amount called for.

Display Name:
Patricia Zdanowski
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe exactly as stated. It didn't say if the four pounds was bone in or boneless, but I went with bone in for the extra flavor. However, after the 5-6 hours of cooking, it was VERY watery so maybe it meant four lbs boneless. To thicken it up, I cooked it on high for an additional two hours with the lid opened for steam to escape. I used sweet baby rays bbq sauce and unfiltered apple cider vinegar. It had a weird after taste that I'm not sure was due to my choices, or just the recipe in general. I would taken another star off for that, but my sister claimed it was the best that she ever had so I gave it back.

Rating:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is delicious! It's a very versatile recipe you can adapt to suit your own tastes. I followed people's suggestions to add cinnamon and cook it on low for 24 hours (I had 20 by the time I was ready to cook). I also strained out the onion and garlic (I added about 8 cloves) after about 12 hours, since my mom is allergic. I served that as "chutney" for the onion-eaters, and it was good. I replaced the sugar with maple syrup and left out most of the chicken stock. Be sure to cook it for a good amount of time after pulling it apart because that's when the flavor really sinks in. I added a bit more bbq sauce after pulling. And use a BIG roast because the leftovers just get better and better! I originally served it over English muffins, then had it on tostadas and in salad. Coleslaw is a MUST. Can't recommend this recipe highly enough!

Made this exactly as instructed and it was awesome. My boyfriend loved it! One mistake I made was placing the roast fat-side-down. Should be on the top so it melts down into the roast!! Yummm. I also used more garlic than called for, about 4 cloves. I froze my leftovers in muffin tins and placed them in a freezer bag once they set the next day. This was a great strategy. About one muffin tin let sandwich. Also so great with rice!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Although this pulled pork was good and very tender, it wasn't perfect. I enjoyed that the pork wasn't completely soaked in BBQ sauce (like so many other recipes where all you taste is the BBQ sauce) but rather, stood alone in a more clear-style sauce. However, the taste of the pork itself was not perfect to me. It was tangy and sweet but not in the right proportions. I wish the meat itself has been saltier and less tangy. I also felt the onion pieces were overpowering, next time I will either chop them finer or quarter them so that they can be removed when the pork is being pulled. Not a bad dish by any means, just not quite what I was hoping to get out of it.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like others, I omitted the oil (no need) and onion (didn't have). I cut the recipe in half and found that 5 and a half hours was plenty of time to cook and fall off the bone. Instead of returning it to a pot full of mostly grease, just served after shredding. The thicker sauces tend to liquefy in the heat so if you like a lot of sauce on yours, set some aside.

userID:
16252591
Display Name:
Kristin Ashley
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2538394.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have always wanted to try pulled pork and I am really impressed with how this turned out! I ended up buying two different cuts of pork (shoulder + rump) that were approximately 0.5kg each. Aside from the type of pork and the amount of pork being a bit less,  I added some chili flakes and some onion + garlic + cumin powder. I started it at 2pm on high, and by 7pm the pork was ready to be shredded, so I did that and put it pack in the pot. I then continued to cook it on high without the lid until 8:30pm to help dissolve some of the juices as there was quite a bit. This might have been a matter of having less pork than what the recipe called for, as well as quite a bit of juice got added from the fat of the meat. I served this on a ciabatta bun with greek yogurt slaw and my partner and I  devoured it! When I took it out the next day to serve left overs, I noticed that there was a significant amount of congealed fat. I think next time I am going to do my best to cook it a day before I want to serve it, just so I can separate the pork from the juices , then the fat from the juice at room temp, and re-add the juice to the pork. I will say choose your BBQ sauce wisely as I feel that different ones will transform the flavor. We used Club House Whiskey Smoked BBQ, I will definitely try this recipe again!

text:
I've made this 3 times now;  most recent was last night.  I thought I'd put in a review!  I personally would add more BBQ sauce (maybe 1/2 cup more?) to give more flavor.  I cooked a 4lb pork butt for 10 hrs on low.  Meat was very tender, but not real flavorful.  I followed recipe exactly, but omitted the oil and thyme.  WAY too much liquid, so I get rid of half of it, then put shredded pork into the saved half of liquid.  I always end up adding more BBQ sauce to thicken and add flavor.  (usually 1 cup).  I will make it again, but will have to have more BBQ sauce on hand.  Oh, and add those french fried onions on top of the pork in the sandwiches!!!  They add crunch and GOOD flavor!  My husband & son will NOT eat these without the fried onions!  BETTER than cole slaw.   Serve the sandwiches with:  corn on cob, baked beans, watermelon, cole slaw, etc....

country:
None
text:
I can't give it 5 stars because I didn't follow the recipe exactly. I omitted the chicken broth and veg oil as my roast had plenty of fat on it for moisture. I feel the thyme would taste off in this so I left it out. I did add chicken bullion for flavor. I added a pint of my homemade BBQ sauce and left out the onion as I was out. It cooked on high for about 5 hours, then on low for another 5. For the last hour of cooking I removed the roast, shredded it with two forks, skimmed the fat from the top on the liquid in the pot and then put the shredded pork back into the liquid. I added a touch of store bought BBQ sauce and let the flavored meld for an other hour. Served on homemade buns.

text:
This is a really good recipe.  I have a small 3.5 L crock pot.  Used 2 smallish roasts (about 1 kg each).  Cooked it on low overnight for 12 hrs.  The meat just fell apart when I took it out to shred.  The recipe does make quite a bit of liquid, but I think all the ingredients should be used to get the right flavour.  I thickened the liquid a bit with 1 TBLSP of corn starch and then poured about 1/2 of it over the meat when I returned the meat to the crockpot for a couple of hours.  Very good - I should have made more!

text:
This was the best pulled pork recipe I've tried.  Everyone raved about it.  I added smoked paprika and used quite a bit more BBQ sauce than the recipe called for.  I used part Stubbs original and part Stubbs spicy.  Just the right amount of heat.  I spent a good 10 minutes skimming fat toward the end of cooking.  I had the meat in the slow cooker on low for 8 1/2 hours and then shredded it.  Very moist.  I served it with grilled pub rolls and creamy spiced coleslaw.  A hit!

country:
None
text:
made a few changes, first off I used a 4pound beef roast, instead of the pork. just what i was in the mood for, omitted the thyme, as suggested in a review, added cinnamon and liquid smoke and cooked in crock pot on low for 22 hours. i feel like it tasted kinda burnt, and a little greasy, so maybe next time i'll omit the oil like suggested. meat had very little fat on it so didnt have to worry about getting it off, fell apart on it's own through out the day, was very good, even so that the pickiest eater in the house went back for seconds :) we served them on toasted grinder rolls, with the tops cut out in a v shape rather then cut on the sides, with butter and shredded cheddar, just put in oven on 400 for a few minutes. got alot of compliments! thanks, def a keeper!!

text:
It was very good. I'll make it again. Tip: Use a slow cooker plastic liner to make clean up super easy! You can find them in ziplock bag isle at the store. It's like a baking bag that you put in your slow cooker. Then when you're ready to clean up you just throw the bag away and you're done! Once you use these liners you'll never go back to the old way again.

Perfect! I mixed the ingredients into a sauce and poured it over the roast in the crock pot (except thyme, didn't have any). I liked it so much, I made it again to reserve as a sauce for serving (brought it to a boil and let it thicken up). Next time, I'll just double the recipe.

text:
My family loves this recipe.  I did a slight variation.  I cooked the meat in 1 can of root beer for 5 hours until it fell apart with a folk, then drained it.  Then I added in the marinade and refrigerated for 24 hours.  I also added in a few tbs. of liquid smoke and a little more garlic.  The next day I reheated it through in the crockpot and served on toasted buns.  The meat was tender and juicy and infused with the bbq flavor.  It really pays to give it that time to marinade.

text:
Made this with a 5 lb. pork shoulder.  Did not use the Thyme as that flavor would not have appealed to me but aside from that this was a GREAT tasting recipe.  Cooked it in the crock pot for 6 hours and it was very tasty.  The only down side to this recipe is that the sauce is a bit runny so when you put the meat on the bun the bread gets soggy very quickly which was a major turn off for my family and what caused us not to rate it with 5 stars.  I feel that this recipe would be better off if used not for sandwiches but for just eating pulled pork, the next time I make this I will eat it that way with garlic/butter toasted bread and a hash brown casserole!  You have to try this recipe it is very good!!!

text:
This is it! The most flavorful slow cooker pulled pork recipe I have ever made or tasted. Please if you are debating between this and the rootbeer one, make this. I have made both and the other pales in comparison. I followed this recipe exactly, except used a 3lb loin roast with the fat trimmed off. Cooked high for 5 hours and kept the crockpot on warm for the rest of the day. About an hour before serving I shredded it up and threw it back in to soak up more flavor. Toasted onion rolls and topped the pork with coleslaw. Perfection! It does make a lot though so I am freezing the leftovers for another meal later this month.

None
text:
This was my first time cooking a pork shoulder, and I guess I didn't realize what a fatty cut of meat it is.  Mine was 7 lbs, bone in, and I adjusted the ingredients accordingly, omitting the chicken stock and vegetable oil.  It took a really long time to cook to the point where it could easily be shredded, probably due to being a bone-in roast.  At the end I had to go through and pick out all the fat and try to skim the sauce.  The amount of fat truly disgusted me and I had a hard time enjoying the meat because of it.  However, it did have a good flavor in the end and my family enjoyed it, so I would make it again, but next time trim off the majority of the fat beforehand.  This would be a great pot luck dish with these adjustments.

This is the best pulled pork ever. Super easy, and everyone loves it. I have made it 3 times in the last few months. I actually get a craving for it. I also have used this sauce recipe as a marinade for brisket. I have a small crock pot, so I cut a 4lb. shoulder in half, freeze the other half to make later. I make the full recipe other than that, and just let it go all day. It makes enough for the 3 of us to eat for supper, and leftovers for the next day.

text:
Thanks for sharing this recipe--it was a hit on the 4th of July! I doubled the recipe for a 5.4 lb roast and made a rub out of the brown sugar, yellow mustard, Worcestershire sauce, chili powder, garlic and thyme. I then seared the roast in the oven at 420F for 30 minutes. I used the same measurements above for the vegetable oil, vinegar, and onion but substituted more chicken broth for BBQ (I like adding it individually) and cooked on high in the slow cooker for 5 hours. A+++

text:
Having friends from out of state and I made this pulled pork recipe in my crock pot.  I followed the recipe to the letter.  It was very easy.  The only thing is that I sired for a minute or 2 on each side before placing the meat into the rock pot. I also made the sauce the night before and placed in a mason jar in the refrigerator  to allow the flavors to blend.  I put this in the crock pot and we went out for brunch and took a leisurely drive in the country.  Came back to a wonderful smell of BBQ throughout the house.  We had this for dinner on toasted buns and also had cole slaw on the side.  We, along with our guest enjoyed it and they insisted on the recipe.  Loved it! I'd rate this a 5.

I've used other recipes for Pulled Pork sandwich and it was easy and great. This one I tried seems got me way too much liquid and too diluted taste. I have to painstakingly taken out the bits of chopped onion and garlic, as my family don't really like them in there. I also have to add more BBQ sauce at the end to get the taste right. Will go back and find my other recipe in the future for pulled pork.

This totally hit the spot.  I omitted the thyme and used some chipotle mustard I had on hand instead of the prepared mustard. I used a 3 1/2 LB pork butt and had it on low (10 hour setting on the crock pot) for about 8 hours. I'll add either some salt or more vinegar next time but the overall taste was great!.  The consistency of the sauce was perfect.  I strained some to use to dip our sandwiches in. I would definitely make this again.

text:
This recipe was amazing!! First i used 2 lbs. skinless and boneless chops because I only have to feed me and my husband, so I halved the recipe but kept 1 cup of BBQ sauce. Before I shredded the pork I drained the juice into a bowl. I put the shredded pork in the crock pot and poured the juice back over until it was the concistancy I wanted. (I was afraid from the other comments it'd be too soupy) It turned out great and my husband really enjoyed it. One of the other firefighters asked for the recipe as I always have to feed at least one of them :)

text:
I'm not a fan of BBQ sauce.  I find it too rich and sweet, and find it overpowers other flavors.  But I am a fan of a good pulled pork sandwich, and this recipe provided the best pulled pork sandwiches I've ever had.  I used Sweet Baby Rays Chipotle BBQ sauce. The meat was moist and delicious, no BBQ on the side required.  The apple cider vinegar makes every bite amazing!  Thank you for the recipe!

text:
Very good. I did make some minor changes. We don't eat pork, so I used a cheap beef roast. I used italian seasoning instead of thyme, and chipotle chili powder. As well I had a beer on hand and used the instead of chicken stock. It was a little spicy for the kids, but they eat some it anyhow. Next time I will cut down the chili powder a bit. Also needed to cook for a full 6 hours on high. I also had to keep adding water to it. Enjoy!

This was the first time I've ever made pulled pork, and I'm telling you it was amazing! The best pulled pork I've ever eaten. Mine was just under 4 lbs. Left it in the slow cooker for about 5 hours on high. It just fell apart. After shredding the meat, we only added some of the liquid back in and mixed in more of the BBQ sauce. Served with grilled Texas toast and potato salad. I'm so proud of how it turned out, and this recipe will be a staple for me now!

Need to adjust it and will try it one more time.  ( I was cooking a 4.5 lb roast)

text:
I used a 5 lb pork roast and, with all the liquid, you can get away with using a bigger piece of meat (6-7 lbs) with the same proportions for the remaining ingredients in the recipe.  I added the onions and garlic to the bottom of the cooker and mixed the liquids together in a bowl before pouring over the roast.  I'd cut the brown sugar down in half (a bit too sweet).  I also used black pepper liberally over the roast.  We have never had pulled pork before today (Super Bowl Sunday) and it will be a great recipe for serving a crowd.

userID:
3681001
Display Name:
gisele
isPro:

followersCount:
1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/835722.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I get great compliments on my pulled pork, and I have used several different recipes- this one is good. I mixed all the ingredients before adding them to the pot. The pork roasts I have used lately are on the fatty side, and since I live in a very rural area, I buy what I can get. Anyhow, I refrigerate the crock pot after the cooking process (usually overnite) to make sure I can get most of the fat out of the meat when I shred it, as well as the layer of fats congealed on the top of the juices. Makes for a much leaner, richer tasting sandwich filling. Toasting the inside of the buns in a skillet makes a world of difference as well. This is an ez ez crowd pleaser.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this recipe was pretty tasty, but like other reviewers, my sauce came out a little bit too thin also. After reading hallshire's review, I dissolved 2 TBS of cornstarch in a small bowl with 1 TBS apple cider as suggested and then dumped it into the sauce once the pork was removed. This did help to thicken up the sauce a lot; yet it still didn't look like the main picture. Maybe this was because I put the shredded pork back into the sauce as stated in the recipe, rather than just spooning it on? I think next time when I take the pork out to be shredded, I will still use hallshire's suggestion, but I will drain half of the liquid out first before adding the corn starch/vinegar mixture. I think I might also spoon the sauce over the pork, instead of dumping the pork back into the sauce so that I can control the amount and not have it be as "soupy". Still a delicious dish and highly recommended! To me this sauce is way more tastier than bottled barbeque sauce.
Review:

text:
I made this exactly by the recipe and it turned out pretty good.  One thing I changed was after shredding the pork I did not put it back in the crock pot with all the juice.  Instead I spooned some of the juice over all the meat and let it marinate in that over night in the fridge.  The next day I heated the meat and poured heated barbecue sauce over it.  It tasted wonderful and everyone loved it!!

text:
Excellent recipe - my family asks for this one regularly! The only thing I change is using onion powder, because onions and I don't get along, and cutting down on the brown sugar slightly and using a tablespoon of honey in its place. Oh, and adding a bit of fresh ground pepper. :) (In addition, if you're not a fan of thyme, you can about halve this and it's still fine. You can't leave it out though - some is still needed. :) ) Definitely five stars!

text:
This recipe had way too much of a vinegar flavor.  I should have caught this before hand but 1/2 cup vinegar with only 1 cup of BBQ sauce was too strong.  I had to add more BBQ Sauce, sugar and some lemon juice to balance the acidity.  I also like spicy BBQ sauce so I added some red pepper flakes and cayenne pepper to taste.  Never really got rid of too much vinegar.  Could have easily done 1/4 cup or less.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I unfortunately did not like the flavor of this pulled pork. It was easy enough to put together - and I followed the directions exactly - except that I used 8 thick pork chops instead of a roast. I cooked them for 4 1/2 hours on high and they fell apart. The flavor was very...pungent. I took the pork out of the crock pot, shredded it, added just a little of the sauce back to it (pureed to take out the chunky texture of the onions), drained the rest of the sauce out of the crock pot, put the pork back in the crock pot and put my favorite BBQ sauce (Sweet Baby Ray's Original) back in. So, I was able to save it, but as written, I didn't like this recipe.

I made this according to the recipe with the exception of deleting Thyme and adding 1 tbs hot sauce, and a couple dashes of liquid smoke.  I whisked all the ingredients toghether. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is wonderful!  I trimmed two pork loin roasts and cut into 3 peices each.  Salt, peppered and coat with BBQ dry rub and placed in fridge overnight.  Also the night before I made mainade only omitted mustard, chili powder and brown sugar.  Then added 1/2 cup honey and 1 can of chipolte peppers (sauce included).  Through it all in the crockpot in the morning.  Cooked 9 hours, shredded and cooked another hour.
